Daniel S (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:00:07

Hi everyone! We‚Äôre ready to start the Simulators and Devices Q&A. We have a number of engineers here that work on simulators in Xcode to answer your questions. You can submit your questions with the :workflowbolt: button. We‚Äôll review your questions and then post them here for everyone to see.

We might not be able to get to all of your questions, but we‚Äôll do our best. As a reminder, please keep the content professional and within our code of conduct.

If you have questions on other topics, you can check to see if there are other Developer Tools Lounge times that might be better suited to your questions. For things not covered here, you can also check for 1-on-1 Developer Labs, or post your questions in the Developer Forums.

üôå Myke S (Apple), Tyler A (Apple), Jason K (Apple), Anand S (Apple), Sam S (Apple), Christian, Arun Prakash
üéâ Angelica B (Apple), Michel, Christian
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 18:05:43

@Ryan asked > Good morning. How can I automatically launch multiple simulators at once by the run keyboard shortcut? (e.g., iPhone 8, iPhone X, iPad, 14.5/16)

Scott T (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:07:45

*Thread Reply:* Xcode doesn't currently support selecting multiple run destinations for the Run action to use. It would be great if you could file a feedback request asking for that feature and provide some details on how/why you'd use it.

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:09:07

*Thread Reply:* Hi Ryan (great name!)

As a follow-up to Scott, the simctl command line tool might be an option for you. It can perform many of the same tasks as Xcode and you can operate it via script

üòÜ Vladimir
Scott T (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:10:53

*Thread Reply:* Another possible alternative that might work for you is to use test plans with schemes to automatically run through a set of tests across multiple devices.

üöÄ Chris
Maxwell O (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:14:32

*Thread Reply:* Hello Ryan, If you are looking to speed up running Unit or UI tests on simulators you could enable an option on your testing targets to ‚ÄúExecute in Parallel‚Äù. This will boot many copied simulators at once and speed up test execution.

Chris
2022-06-07 18:29:10

*Thread Reply:* @Scott T (Apple) & @Maxwell O (Apple) these are both awesome options! Consume them all of the time across all sorts of language and hardware combinations.

Ryan
2022-06-07 18:47:33

*Thread Reply:* @Ryan B (Apple) @Scott T (Apple) I'll check your suggestions out. One use case is, before submitting a PR with UI work, I like "see to believe" one last time, preferably on sims already setup with various accessibility settings or staging environment user accounts. It would be great to mix in with my live test devices, one of which is always on a verbose VoiceOver setting.

Scott T (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:53:05

*Thread Reply:* I'd encourage you to look at test plans with a combination of unit tests and UI tests to automate some of that confidence building. Where you are using Swift UI you can also use previews to get better visual coverage of changes made to the UI.

Zev
2022-06-07 19:06:00

*Thread Reply:* Snapshot tests (not from Apple, but there are libraries) are also a great tool here. They let you record snapshots of views and then diff the images if they change.

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 18:09:56

@Rens asked > I'm working on an Apple Watch app that uses compass heading for navigation. However, the debugging on an actual watch is slow. Is there a way to simulate compass data using the watchOS Simulator?

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:10:37

*Thread Reply:* I believe the compass requires physical sensors on device, and therefore it is not available in Simulator

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:11:21

*Thread Reply:* As always, file feedback using Feedback Assistant if this is important to you!

Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:11:48

*Thread Reply:* Indeed, we do not currently support simulating Compass but we would be interested in hearing about your use case in detail

Rens
2022-06-07 18:16:20

*Thread Reply:* Thanks, I filed a feedback for this last year and was hoping to see it this year. I had already checked the simulator but did not find the feature. The feedback number is FB9161848

The use case is an app for theme parks, these locations are poorly mapped if mapped at all. So I wanted to offer a simple navigation using an arrow indicating the direction. And a similar case for a public water fountain finder for Apple Watch

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:19:08

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for your feedback

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 18:11:58

@Jack asked > Hi, are there plans to include network link conditioning into Xcode/simulators so that we can simulate bad network connections on apps running in simulators without impacting the entire computer's internet connection (or requiring the use of software like Charles or Proxyman)?

Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:12:42

*Thread Reply:* Each Simulator is a separate userspace but shares the kernel and networking stack with macOS so there is not presently a way to do this.

Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:13:18

*Thread Reply:* But we are aware of the desire for this!

‚ù§Ô∏è Jack, Marco Antonio, Denis, Adrien, Richard
üëç Enrico, Radu, Daria, Wei, Martin
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 18:12:21

@Sara asked > Good day! How can I change simulators location and language programmatically? My primary use case is Unit Tests need to check multiple locations and languages and am hoping for a better option than shell scripts that change plist files...

üôå Yoni, Kirill
Ethan V (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:12:50

*Thread Reply:* In your test plan file, there's a "Simulated Location" setting for configuring the system location, as well as an "Application Language" setting.

Ethan V (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:15:02

*Thread Reply:* If you need to change the system location/application language outside of a testing context, could you file a feedback assistant requesting this?

Sara
2022-06-07 18:17:20

*Thread Reply:* TestPlans allow for a change to the App Language and Region, but not the System Lang/Region

Sara
2022-06-07 18:18:37

*Thread Reply:* And for testing things like various UTF formatting (Currency definitely comes to mind), it really helps to be able to change the System levels

Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:31:12

*Thread Reply:* Currently Simulator does not surface a UI to change this directly. Instead of manipulating plists you can use simctl to spawn the defaults utility inside a given Simulator: xcrun simctl spawn &lt;device&gt; defaults write -globalDomain AppleLanguages -array en-US fr-FR

üôå Al, Witold, Ruslan
:thumbsup_all: Sara
Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:31:26

*Thread Reply:* The same goes for the AppleLocale

@Andr√© asked > How can I build and run in the command line using the "My Mac (Designed for iPad)" destination? I've tried xcrun simctl list devices, but it does not have this destination.

Jeremy S (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:19:03

*Thread Reply:* xcrun simctl list devices shows simulator devices. To get a list of supported run destinations to pass to xcodebuild from the command line, check xcodebuild -showdestinations .

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 18:19:27

@Jade asked > Simulators and previews take up a ton of space on my Mac. I noticed in particular Previews keeps growing and growing to the point where the previews folder in the developer folder takes up more that 100gigs of space. Is there a way to limit the amount of space previews and simulators take up, and if so what is the best and safest way to clear that space?

Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:20:44

*Thread Reply:* There were some known issues with Xcode 13 that should be fixed in Xcode 14. Please file a feedback request with the disk space usage output from a program like GrandPerspective if you can. We would like to know what files are taking up the space and if you still see the issue in Xcode 14.

üëç:skin_tone_2: Radu
üëç Yi-Shan, Jade
Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:21:20

*Thread Reply:* In the mean time you can use xcrun simctl erase to erase simulators you don't need anymore.

Jade
2022-06-07 18:22:11

*Thread Reply:* Thank you!

Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:22:43

*Thread Reply:* Previews, Interface Builder, and Playgrounds use separate device sets which you can specify. So for example to list all Previews simulators: xcrun simctl --set previews list Then do the same with the erase/delete subcommands.

üôè Jade, Christopher, Max
Rafaela
2022-06-07 18:37:33

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for this question, just removed almost 100gb of previews files today üôÇ

Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:26:34

*Thread Reply:* Is this specifically about such errors when building for Simulator? If this is a general project build issue please come back for the Xcode Open Hours Lab.

Brandon
2022-06-07 18:27:06

*Thread Reply:* Good question, @Russ B (Apple). I didn't even think to try on-device vs. Simulator. I'll come back for Open Hours. Thank you!

Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:27:33

*Thread Reply:* If this is Simulator specific then can you tell us if you are on an Apple Silicon Mac or not? Missing symbols errors are often a result of a link time dependency being missing or using a binary dependency that doesn't have all the architectures required

Brandon
2022-06-07 18:28:37

*Thread Reply:* This is indeed on an Apple Silicon machine (running Xcode 14 in Rosetta). Regretfully, the app I work on has quite a few dependencies outside of my control, requiring Rosetta, but the aforementioned symbol error is seemingly the last barrier standing in my way to getting the app to run on Xcode 14.

Scott T (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:31:00

*Thread Reply:* There is also the Xcode Build Performance lab on Thursday (9am-1pm) where they are happy to field questions about getting your project to build properly.

Myke S (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:31:06

üôå Al

*Thread Reply:* Thanks @Russ B (Apple) @Scott T (Apple) @Myke S (Apple)! I will make an appointment if I'm not able to resolve it!

Jeremy S (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:37:56

*Thread Reply:* Please be sure to come prepared with a build log for folks to look through. It might even be quicker to post your question (and log) in the developer forums. If you do so, please provide a link to the dev forums in this thread to connect the conversations.

üëç Brandon
Ivan
2022-06-07 20:07:56

*Thread Reply:* Just want to confirm the issue and add some additional information and observations. We have a project that depends on XCFramework distributed through SPM, that contains frameworks for ios-arm64 and ios-arm64-simulator (basically iPhone and Simulator on M1 Mac. Everything works fine on Xcode 13 but on Xcode 13 the framework does not link properly. Judging from the error message: ‚Äúwarning build: Ignoring file ‚Äú/path to binary/‚Äú, building for iOS Simulator-x86_64 but attempting to link with file built for iOS Simulator-arm64‚Äù it appears that for some reason Xcode tries to build for x86 Simulator architecture, which is obviously not correct considering that Xcode runs without Rosetta and on a M1 Mac. My biggest fear is that this behavior somehow slipped into new version as a way of ‚Äòfixing‚Äô a major problem with old-style fat-frameworks that contain a slice for x86 simulator and thus de-facto break Simulator on M1 machines, and people do all sorts of terrible things with their project to hot-fix the problem.

P.S. For folks interested in details there is great blog post by Bogo Giertler titled ‚ÄúHacking native ARM64 binaries to run on the iOS Simulator‚Äù.

Ivan
2022-06-07 20:12:43

*Thread Reply:* Small follow-up: our project depends on framework that only distributed for arm64 (which is not uncommon) so on x86 machines we don‚Äôt have simulator, but we managed to get everything working on m1's by duplicating and modifying an arm64 slice to iphonesimulator and creating xcframework with it, which greatly improved our dev experience. I truly hope what we see on Xcode 14 is bug.

Alexander
2022-06-07 20:13:05

*Thread Reply:* @Brandon I have successfully converted one of our projects to build successfully for the arm64 simulator, but every library, every case is different. In our case, I have two cases:

  1. Recompile the library for the arm64 simulator, and then link different libraries for device and simulator (if you want to go the extra mile, build an xcframework)
  2. Find a new (in our case) beta version of the dependency we used
  3. What @Ivan pointed
Ivan
2022-06-07 20:15:54

*Thread Reply:* Also forgot to mention that undefined symbols problem mention in the beginning results from framework not linking and xcode treating this as a warning and not an error, so the build pipeline continues without necessary symbols. I submitted the overall bug report with the following reference: FB10068243

Brandon
2022-06-08 00:57:20

*Thread Reply:* Thanks, @Alexander! In my case, our frameworks and dependencies are building fine on Apple Silicon in Xcode 13.4.1 (running in Rosetta), but I'm getting an error doing the same in Xcode 14, and was hoping to get going with Xcode 14 during WWDC!

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 18:30:55

@Grant asked > Will it ever be possible to simulate accessibility gestures (such as the VoiceOver ‚ÄúZ‚Äù gesture and the rotor) in the simulator, especially in calls from UI Tests?

‚ôø Grant, Rob
Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:31:50

*Thread Reply:* We can't discuss what might or might not be coming in future releases. If this is important to you, please file feedback through Feedback Assistant

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:32:06

*Thread Reply:* It would also be helpful to know your use case

Grant
2022-06-07 18:40:03

*Thread Reply:* Anything that can‚Äôt be put into either, or both of, unit or UI tests, can‚Äôt be counted on to keep working as we continue to develop our code. Everything we rely on our code to do should be testable. ‚ÄúWhat gets measured matters‚Äù and automated tests are a key tool of ‚Äúmeasuring‚Äù our code, and maintaining good engineering practice.

Right now, accessibility interactions are subject to significant risk of regressions because we have to resort to manual testing in our apps.

It feels like, while Apple has developed some incredible, and sometimes life-changing, accessibility features, they‚Äôve only gone half way by leaving them out of automated testing.

Ethan V (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:51:10

*Thread Reply:* We definitely agree with you on the importance of being able to test the accessibility features of your app! There's no UI testing API today for automating the VoiceOver gestures you listed, but this would be a great enhancement. If you capture that request into a feedback assistant, it would be really appreciated. You can also check out one of the "Xcode Cloud and testing open hours" labs to discuss this use case.

üëç Grant, Adi
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 18:36:09

@Mayurgiri asked > Hello everyone, for Xcode project having large codebase, every time if its a clean build or branch change, Xcode start preparing the indexing which causes whole mac system makes so much slower until indexing task completes. Any workaround or tips for it?

‚ûï Daniil, Yoni
Han Ming O (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:38:51

*Thread Reply:* Hi there, indexing is an integral part of Xcode so that other features like Source Editor will work optimally. If indexing is causing your system to be slow, please file a feedback using Feedback Assistant. We will follow up to ask for logs so that we can triage the problem correctly.

Edward
2022-06-07 19:46:24

*Thread Reply:* How about breaking your code into Swift Packages?

Daniil
2022-06-07 22:01:27

*Thread Reply:* I have the same issue. There are two threads about this issue on the forum: https://developer.apple.com/forums/thread/694058 https://developer.apple.com/forums/thread/699112 This issue is still present in Xcode 14 :-(

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 18:36:58

@Asaf asked > Hey guys! In order to inject a dynamic library to an application we use xcrun simctl launch with SIMCTL_CHILD_DYLD_INSERT_LIBRARIES argument, which works only for iOS Simulators of course. What is the alternative for iOS real (hardware) devices?

Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:37:59

*Thread Reply:* This is not something supported for on-device debugging for iOS, watchOS, or tvOS. The system only allows a specific approved list of dylibs to be injected (the ones used by Xcode for things like View Debugger).

Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:38:23

*Thread Reply:* You must build and link any dylibs you want to use with your app.

Asaf
2022-06-07 18:41:25

*Thread Reply:* Thanks @Russ B (Apple)! Is there a reason behind why you don‚Äôt enable this for on-device debugging? Even if the app is code signed by you?

Jeremy S (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:44:08

*Thread Reply:* Is there a use case you have that isn't solved by directly linking in your dylibs?

Asaf
2022-06-07 18:53:51

*Thread Reply:* Yes, for example I have some library that I‚Äôd like to insert only from CI agents for debugging (logging and monitoring) purposes

Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:56:10

*Thread Reply:* So is the issue that you want your CI to build once, make the artifacts available everywhere, but only load your logging library when running tests in CI?

üëÄ Asaf
Asaf
2022-06-07 18:56:45

*Thread Reply:* Exactly

Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:58:48

*Thread Reply:* So there is not an easily supported way to do this but in theory if you weak link the dylib and include it in your build you could take the built app, remove the dylib from its bundle, then resign it to update the list of resources in the bundle. Trying that will be very fragile and I don't recommend it because you will be fighting xcodebuild the entire way.

ü§î Asaf
Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:59:17

*Thread Reply:* Instead I recommend you include your code and use some kind of switch to enable or disable it at startup.

Asaf
2022-06-07 19:06:43

*Thread Reply:* > Instead I recommend you include your code and use some kind of switch to enable or disable it at startup. It feels very risky to have this code part of the app, I want this to be as far as possible from production üòÑ

Asaf
2022-06-07 19:09:55

*Thread Reply:* > So there is not an easily supported way to do this but in theory if you weak link the dylib and include it in your build you could take the built app, remove the dylib from its bundle, then resign it to update the list of resources in the bundle. Trying that will be very fragile and I don‚Äôt recommend it because you will be fighting xcodebuild the entire way. Interesting, what kind of fighting? Is there anything specific you can think of?

Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:23:06

*Thread Reply:* Normally you would build the app for distribution if we are talking about a device build. You'd need to unwrap that, make the change, resign the app bundle manually with all the correct flags and the correct signing identity, then get it packaged back up for distribution.

Jeremy S (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:23:17

*Thread Reply:* Also, in order to weak link it, the dylib (or tbd) actually needs to be there. So you'd need to build it even though you don't use it, which is not ideal. As you start to unwind all of that with various build settings, I expect you'd converge on adding it to OTHERLDFLAGS[config=Debug] (or similar) and adding something to GCCPREPROCESSORDEFINITIONS[config=Debug] to only use and link it in your debug configuration.

Asaf
2022-06-07 20:07:38

*Thread Reply:* > So you‚Äôd need to build it even though you don‚Äôt use it, which is not ideal indeed üòï

Asaf
2022-06-07 20:09:03

*Thread Reply:* OK, thanks for the answers guys

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 18:41:14

@Stephen asked > Will it ever be possible to get the Apple Watch battery level via 3rd party apps? I do not see any documentation for this.

Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:41:40

*Thread Reply:* I'd recommend bringing this to the watchOS Developer Lab. They'd be able to give better guidance than we can

@Al asked > When running UI tests, we sporadically get an error like this inside of XCTest (when trying to do element queries), and it seems like it persists until restarting the simulator. üì° Ashton
Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:55:01

*Thread Reply:* Is this a crash happening in your application code, your test code, or an Apple framework?

Han Ming O (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:55:55

*Thread Reply:* To help you with your triage, you can create an Exception Breakpoint in the Breakpoint Navigator, run your test and examine your backtrace.

Han Ming O (Apple)
2022-06-07 18:57:11

*Thread Reply:* Note that the exception will be raised in Foundation framework but the important stack frames are the ones that set up the NSArray

üëç Al
Al
2022-06-07 18:58:44

2022-06-07 19:00:44

Al
2022-06-07 19:01:39

Han Ming O (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:02:49

*Thread Reply:* You can leave your Exception breakpoint on until you see the problem. In terms of performance impact, it is minimal. You can choose to delete the breakpoint after that.

2022-06-07 19:03:13

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 19:00:53

@Nathan asked > For purely logical unit tests (i.e. a Unit Test bundle - not UI Unit Tests), what difference is there between running the tests on the simulator versus running them in catalyst? If I'm not planning on distributing my app via catalyst, would it make running unit tests using them less helpful? I like running them in catalyst, because it seems to be easier to automate - but I don't know if there are downsides to running them like that.

Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:01:26

*Thread Reply:* This depends on what your code does and what your testing goals are.

Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:03:11

*Thread Reply:* Simulator and Catalyst have different behavior in various ways (for example Simulator treats all filesystem access as case-sensitive even on macOS where most volumes are not which helps catch errors). The Catalyst environment is also tied to the version of macOS you are running unlike Simulator. Simulator is also a separate environment with its own Photo Library, Contacts, and so forth so it doesn't affect your Mac.

Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:03:16

*Thread Reply:* Those things may or may not matter to you.

Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:03:57

*Thread Reply:* If your unit tests are just exercising data structures or doing straightforward CRUD operations on a database then you can certainly run them under Catalyst.

Nathan
2022-06-07 19:09:46

*Thread Reply:* Thank you - I'm actually trying to just test out basic functionality of a shared cross-platform library that we are starting to port to iOS. I think that the Catalyst environment is probably sufficient for what we would want in this initial phase.

However, we may at some point benefit from being able to run unit tests on a simulator as well - are there many differences between the simulator and a physical device as it pertains to unit testing? Are there ways to automate the execution of unit tests on the simulator as well? (Sorry for the basic questions - this is the first we've dealt with development for iOS...yeah - we're late to the game! üôÇ)

Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:11:47

*Thread Reply:* Not as it pertains to unit testing unless you have specific hardware needs like BT. And yes you can automate on simulators. Many developers test on both and that is what I would also recommend.

Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:12:19

*Thread Reply:* If you want to build your own automation outside of what Xcode provides you can check out xcrun simctl as well.

üëç Nathan

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 19:30:23

@Sean asked > At home when I recently updated my router from an old AirPort Extreme to a mesh Orbi system, wireless debugging has stopped working and I can never get it to work. Is there any known issues with mesh networks and wireless debugging?

Anand S (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:32:35

*Thread Reply:* As a first troubleshooting step, I would recommend checking whether your wireless network is filtering Bonjour/mDNS traffic. Devices which have been configured for wireless development advertise their presence via bonjour and Xcode depends on this traffic to discover and connect to these devices.

Anand S (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:34:05

*Thread Reply:* You can also check whether other devices on your network which you normally expect to be discoverable via bonjour are discoverable on your new WiFi network. That can help isolate whether the issues are specific to your development workflows or all workflows which depend on Bonjour.

Sean
2022-06-07 19:35:11

*Thread Reply:* AirPrint does work, but not sure if that uses Bonjour‚Ä¶.thanks for the thoughts, I‚Äôll take a look

Anand S (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:35:18

*Thread Reply:* If neither of those steps work, please send us a feedback report and include a sysdiagnose from the mac running Xcode and the device on which you would like to develop.

Jamus
2022-06-07 19:37:18

*Thread Reply:* @Sean (I‚Äôm not an Apple Employee, but thought I would interject)‚Ä¶I found the free app ‚ÄúFlame Services Browser‚Äù useful for browsing bonjour. I‚Äôve used it on iOS, and looks like it‚Äôs available for macOS. Thought that may help.

üôå Sean
Rens
2022-06-07 19:44:28

*Thread Reply:* Also dropping in (not an Apple employee), we had this issue at my previous company as well we used an Asus router and figured out that ‚ÄúAirtime Fairness‚Äù was causing debugging not to work.

Not sure how this fixed it, but it might have been a broken implementation. So that is a step you could try as well.

üôå Stanislav, Ben
üëç Ben

Anand S (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:50:53

*Thread Reply:* Hi Edward, macOS Ventura requires Xcode 14.

Edward
2022-06-07 19:51:49

*Thread Reply:* I was coming to that conclusion. Any advice on installing Monterey on a volume?

Eric
2022-06-07 19:52:52

*Thread Reply:* https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT208891

Apple Support
Use more than one version of macOS on a Mac
If you install a compatible macOS on a new volume of your built-in startup disk, your Mac can start up from either volume.¬†It's an easy way to use a newer macOS while keeping a previously installed macOS for software that might require it.
Original URL: https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT208891
Edward
2022-06-07 19:54:13

*Thread Reply:* I set up a volume to install Ventura, stepped away for a little bit, and found the update was installing over Monterey üòû. It's working great - good job, but need access to Xcode 13.

Russ B (Apple)
2022-06-07 19:55:56

*Thread Reply:* When you start the macOS installer you should be able to select a different volume to have it install to a separate one. Or you can use the createinstallmedia utility inside the installer bundle to make an installer disk, then restart holding Option and select that disk as the boot disk.

Eric
2022-06-07 19:57:57

*Thread Reply:* Make sure to run the installer in a way you can select the volume. I guess that volume can now be for Monterey ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT201372

Apple Support
How to create a bootable installer for macOS
You can use an external drive or secondary volume as a startup disk from which to install the Mac operating system.
Original URL: https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT201372

2022-06-07 19:59:46

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 20:00:23

@Stacey asked > When testing my app over different simulators it creates multiple instances of simulator which over time cause simulator to become unresponsive. The only fix I have found for this is to quit and relaunch the simulator, which in turn causes me to have to rebuild for each instance. Is there an easier way to clean my cache without me having to start over?

Ethan V (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:01:29

*Thread Reply:* It's possible to run your app on the simulator without rebuilding it, via the Product &gt; Perform Action &gt; Run without Building menu item.

Ethan V (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:02:47

*Thread Reply:* Using that action (and the similar action for testing, Product &gt; Perform Action &gt; Test without Building) can avoid unnecessary rebuilds in between launches of Xcode or the simulator.

Stacey
2022-06-07 20:16:55

*Thread Reply:* Ok, I will give that a try! Thanks so much!

Daniel S (Apple)

If you have questions on other topics, you can check to see if there are other Developer Tools Lounge times that might be better suited to your questions. For things not covered here, you can also check for 1-on-1 Developer Labs, or post your questions in the Developer Forums.

2022-06-07 20:08:07

@Vladislav asked > Can I use SPM to build executable binaries for non apple platforms, like example Windows or Platform.custom(‚Äúnintendo‚Äù)?

Steve C (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:10:23

*Thread Reply:* Swift core team member "compnerd" (Saleem) has been working on windows support for SwiftPM. Something like "nintendo" would require that someone else from the community make a similar effort.

Nate C (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:13:41

*Thread Reply:* You can find out about platforms Swift supports for development and deployment here: https://www.swift.org/platform-support/

swift.org
Swift.org
Swift is a general-purpose programming language built using a modern approach to safety, performance, and software design patterns.
Original URL: https://www.swift.org/platform-support/
Vladislav
2022-06-07 20:23:15

*Thread Reply:* Ok, what the point to use Platform.custom()? And can simple developer create custom product type, like ApplePlatforms SDK?

Nate C (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:33:22

*Thread Reply:* Great question! Platform.custom(_:) is intended for use when someone is adding support for a new platform to SwiftPM. During the development process, and before that official support is added, you can use the .custom API

üëç Steve C (Apple), Vladislav
Vladislav
2022-06-07 20:38:52

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 20:14:00

@Toke asked > What is the reason for Swift Regex only being available in iOS, is it because it's a part of the standard library not the swift language it self? If so would it be possible to ship the standard library with our app to gain backwards compatibility like we did before we had ABI stability?

Fabian F (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:17:02

*Thread Reply:* The swift regex API is available on all Apple platforms. See the documentation here: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/regexbuilder

Guillaume L (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:17:14

*Thread Reply:* It‚Äôs because it‚Äôs part of the standard library. The minimum deployment target is iOS 16 and macOS 13. You can deploy to macOS if you target the beta macOS.

Steve C (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:18:00

*Thread Reply:* You cannot ship the standard library with your app.

Toke
2022-06-07 20:19:23

*Thread Reply:* But being able to would be extremely good, that way new features could be supported on older iOS versions. For something like regex I will have to wait at least two years befor I can use it‚Ä¶

‚òùÔ∏è:skin_tone_4: Joshua
Steve C (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:25:44

*Thread Reply:* There are some technical problems with having types defined in multiple modules (the standard library shipped with your app and the standard library that the SDK frameworks your app interacts with are linked against), so simply including the standard library with your app cannot work.

If having specific features be back-deployable to older OSes is important for you, that's a great request to provide via feedback assistant.

üëç Toke

2022-06-07 20:28:40

I've seen articles written in 2022 still recommending that people buy iPhone 7 who can't afford newer phones, and I still have multiple family members who use iPhone 7. It seems like a particularly large burden this year to either drop or continue support for iPhone 7.

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 20:14:52

@Ratnesh asked > When to use class and actor?

üëç Yoni
Robert W (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:17:41

*Thread Reply:* Good Swift style generally revolves around the use of structs instead of classes. However, if you must use a class to model something, generally you should ask if you need to protect some shared resource or state. This comes up very frequently when using async-await and Swift's other concurrency features. If you find yourself using async-await it's good to start with an actor to protect the state of the type from concurrent modifications. So when do you use classes? Generally when you need a type that has a built-in notion of identity, or when interacting with other languages like Objective-C that require subclassing.

üëå Steve C (Apple)
üëç Stanislav, Andrew T (Apple), Dustin
Robert W (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:24:40

*Thread Reply:* For more information please see "Protect mutable state with Swift actors" from WWDC 2021 https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2021/10133/

Apple Developer
Protect mutable state with Swift actors - WWDC21 - Videos - Apple Developer
Data races occur when two separate threads concurrently access the same mutable state. They are trivial to construct, but are notoriously...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2021/10133/
Ratnesh
2022-06-07 20:27:51

*Thread Reply:* Thanks, like in a SwiftUI project‚Äôs view model where one method fetches data from remote and update the some properties. In this class with @MainActor is used if that property read/observed by any UI part?

Doug G (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:29:08

*Thread Reply:* Yes, if the class has an instance property that is read/observed by the UI, you will need a @MainActor class.

‚ù§Ô∏è Ratnesh
Ratnesh
2022-06-07 20:32:54

*Thread Reply:* And to communicate between actors and other data types, the property should be of sendable type?

Robert W (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:34:33

*Thread Reply:* Yes, in general you should ensure that types are Sendable when crossing concurrency boundaries, including async calls. The Swift compiler has warnings and errors in place to catch a wide variety of errors that can potentially occur when writing this kind of code.

Doug G (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:34:47

*Thread Reply:* Yes, only Sendable types can be safely passed amongst different actors and tasks. The session "Eliminate data races using Swift Concurrency" (https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/110351/) goes into detail on Sendable types and how they interact with tasks and actors.

Apple Developer
Eliminate data races using Swift Concurrency - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
Join us as we explore one of the core concepts in Swift concurrency: isolation of tasks and actors. We'll take you through Swift's...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/110351/
‚ù§Ô∏è Ratnesh, Thomas
üôå Robert W (Apple)
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 20:22:43

@Adrian asked > SwiftUI and Swift Standard Library sometimes rely on emitting public protocols with underscored/hidden requirements that end up in module interface but ‚Äì crucially ‚Äì not in code completion or documentation. I would find this extremely useful as a framework vendor. Is there a way to achieve this using a special flag or attribute?

Karoy L (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:22:54

*Thread Reply:* All names beginning with an underscore are hidden by default from code completion and documentation. The Swift Standard Library and some of the packages we maintain rely on this feature to hide entry points that need to be public for technical reasons but aren‚Äôt part of the module‚Äôs public API. Feel free to use the same convention in your own modules!

üôå Adrian, Eric, Roland, Yoni
Adrian
2022-06-07 20:26:10

*Thread Reply:* Thank you for taking the time to answer my question, Karoy! That‚Äôs great news.

üëç Karoy L (Apple)
Steve C (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:26:35

*Thread Reply:* Note that you can also hide inits and subscripts by underscoring their argument labels.

üòØ Adrian, Yi-ying, Leonard, Roland, Martin
Adrian
2022-06-07 20:28:39

*Thread Reply:* Ha, nice! I would‚Äôve never discovered this. Thanks!

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 20:30:14

@Sean asked > Other than being open source, is Apple really interested in advancing Swift on the server? I'd love to replace some Spring Boot webservices with Swift that use Kafka/Cassandra...unfortunately the community and support just doesn't yet seem mature enough. Is this just a dream of mine or is this a priority for Apple?

Fabian F (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:30:53

*Thread Reply:* Hey Sean, thanks for your question. Apple is committed to advancing Swift on Server. This is why we have three employees participate in the Swift on Server workgroup. Further we mentor in the google summer of code, where one project is a kafka library. (https://summerofcode.withgoogle.com/programs/2022/projects/5nq3GuxI).

Regarding your wish for a cassandra client, I have noted this and will bring this feedback to the SSWG.

summerofcode.withgoogle.com
Google Summer of Code
Google Summer of Code is a global program focused on bringing more developers into open source software development.
Original URL: https://summerofcode.withgoogle.com/programs/2022/projects/5nq3GuxI

2022-06-07 20:31:06

swift.org
Swift.org
Swift is a general-purpose programming language built using a modern approach to safety, performance, and software design patterns.
Original URL: https://www.swift.org/sswg/

üòÜ Sean
Sean
2022-06-07 20:45:49

*Thread Reply:* To be honest, I haven‚Äôt taken a very hard look at it in about 2 years, but keeping me in SpringBoot is probably just the plethora of support for nearly anything that may come along requirements-wise. Off the top of my head would be Kafka, Cassandra, WebSockets, and support for securing APIs using a plethora of ways (keycloak, ping, etc - -spring security plugins seems to be available for everything).

Maybe it is time for me to go back and take another look at using it

Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:51:52

*Thread Reply:* Thanks @Sean

Sean
2022-06-07 21:04:42

*Thread Reply:* Thank you, @Tony P (Apple)

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 20:42:23

@Eric asked > What is the plan for XPC support in Distributed Actors? Will there be support or will that be left to the community?

David S (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:42:34

*Thread Reply:* We‚Äôre always interested in improving our APIs, but can‚Äôt comment on unreleased products or future plans. If you have specific enhancements you‚Äôd find useful, please file feedbacks requesting them

Doug G (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:43:56

*Thread Reply:* Distributed Actors is designed to work across multiple transport mechanisms and with different ways of encoding/decoding data, so it should be possible to build an XPC transport that integrates fully with the language feature. The session "Meet distributed actors in Swift" (https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/110356/) discusses several transport mechanisms.

Apple Developer
Meet distributed actors in Swift - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
Discover distributed actors ‚Äî an extension of Swift's actor model that simplifies development of distributed systems. We'll explore how...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/110356/
üëç Eric
Eric
2022-06-07 20:49:50

*Thread Reply:* Thanks. This session is top of my list. I'm looking for ways to clean up my XPC communication code between processes.

Thomas
2022-06-07 20:50:26

*Thread Reply:* is this Distributed framework in the docs a repackaged version of https://github.com/apple/swift-distributed-actors

GitHub
GitHub - apple/swift-distributed-actors: Peer-to-peer cluster implementation for Swift Distributed Actors
Peer-to-peer cluster implementation for Swift Distributed Actors - GitHub - apple/swift-distributed-actors: Peer-to-peer cluster implementation for Swift Distributed Actors
Original URL: https://github.com/apple/swift-distributed-actors
üëç Eric
Doug G (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:54:15

*Thread Reply:* No, they are different things. The Distributed module provides the basic protocols and types needed to interact with the distributed actor feature of the language, e.g., the DistributedActor protocol, DistributedActorSystem protocol, etc. The swift-distributed-actors package you reference is one implementation of a distributed actor system (what I referred to as a "transport" above) for clusters. Other packages could provide alternative distributed actor system implementations for different environments.

:the_horns: Eric
Thomas
2022-06-07 20:56:46

*Thread Reply:* so if i wanted to implement a server-side distributed counterpart to a mac app, say, i‚Äôd want to use something like the above, as long as it conforms to the DistributedActors protocols?

Eric
2022-06-07 21:06:34

*Thread Reply:* Can the Distributed module be baked in to an app if targeting macOS 12?

Doug G (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:06:45

*Thread Reply:* Yes, you could implement a new type that conforms to DistributedActorSystem, which communicates over HTTP or sockets or whatever with your server, and then your distributed actor types could communicate over that. I expect other packages with implementations of DistributedActorSystem will crop up in time.

Doug G (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:07:25

*Thread Reply:* No, the Distributed module cannot be baked into an app for targeting macOS 12. It's only available in macOS 13 / iOS 16-era OS's

Eric
2022-06-07 21:08:35

*Thread Reply:* Thanks. Is this a macOS/iOS only feature at this point or will it be available to Linux too?

Doug G (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:09:22

*Thread Reply:* It's also available on Linux!

:the_horns: Eric
Doug G (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:09:58

*Thread Reply:* Any recent Swift 5.7 Linux toolchain from https://www.swift.org/download/ provides support for distributed actors

swift.org
Swift.org
Swift is a general-purpose programming language built using a modern approach to safety, performance, and software design patterns.
Original URL: https://www.swift.org/download/
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 20:43:57

@Ratnesh asked > When converting a blocking method to async like Foundation.Process‚Äôs waitUntilExit() will block the current thread, so do we embed that logic to a continuation block, or just making function async is enough?

Robert W (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:44:10

*Thread Reply:* You are correct that waitUntilExit() will block the current thread, and is therefore not appropriate. You can use Process.terminationHandler as an appropriate place to resume the continuation https://developer.apple.com/documentation/foundation/process/1408746-terminationhandler

üôå Ratnesh
Ratnesh
2022-06-07 20:45:55

*Thread Reply:* Awesome, that sounds perfect ü§©

Aura Lily V (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:58:28

*Thread Reply:* An extra note: you may want to set the termination handler from a thread that has a run loop running, which is hard to guarantee using a task. The easiest way is to set up your task on the main actor before launching it.

Aura Lily V (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:59:52

*Thread Reply:* You also can use continuations to convert your termination handler use to async/await; check out withCheckedContinuation(‚Ä¶) for that.

Aura Lily V (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:00:48

*Thread Reply:* https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swift/withcheckedcontinuation(function::)|https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swift/withcheckedcontinuation(function::)

üëç Ratnesh
Ratnesh
2022-06-07 21:25:37

*Thread Reply:* Thanks. I think I need to request for lab appointment for more details üòÖü§û:skintone2:.

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 20:51:35

@Yi-ying asked > Saw Foundation team merged the Foundation Swift Overlay into Foundation.framework. > Does it mean entire Swift runtime will be loaded and linked as part of Foundation (for a pure Obj-C project) for iOS 16 unconditionally? Trying to understand what extra cost there will be during app launch (for a zero-swift project but import Foundation).

Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:53:22

*Thread Reply:* Hi @Yi-ying! Great question, thanks for asking. We‚Äôve done a lot of measurements on this with the apps that ship with the system and made a ton of small improvements all over the place to make sure that any additional dirty memory cost was ‚Äòpaid for‚Äô

üëç Steve C (Apple), Eric, Yi-ying
üôå Robert W (Apple), Eric
Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:55:13

*Thread Reply:* If you see any regressions or other issues, please do reach out so we can investigate. Probably via a bug report if it‚Äôs after this lab is done

Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:56:10

*Thread Reply:* One thing to note here is that part of what we did is swap around some dependencies that previously were brought in when you import Foundation. That will bring in a lot fewer other libraries now

:the_horns: Eric, Yi-ying, Miguel S (Apple)
Yi-ying
2022-06-07 21:01:23

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for answering this the measurement works! Not sure if I understand it correctly. Do you mean that ‚Äúthough now whole Swift runtime is linked even for a pure objc project, there will be less dependencies. So the overall impact is neutral‚Äù ?

Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:23:38

*Thread Reply:* It turns out that ‚Äúthe whole swift runtime‚Äù is actually not that big of a dependency, basically

üëç Yi-ying
Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:23:56

*Thread Reply:* It's a small runtime library plus the standard library

Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:24:41

*Thread Reply:* We add in a few more like the overlays for dispatch and XPC; but on Apple‚Äôs platforms these are all cached and the impact to launch should be really small, if it's even measurable

Yi-ying
2022-06-07 21:29:29

*Thread Reply:* @Tony P (Apple) Really appreciate the detailed answers and all the amazing works you‚Äôve done!

üëç Tony P (Apple)
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 20:59:10

@Stefan asked > There are so many different means to approach concurrency, or even asynchronous development in iOS today. Does GCD and operations still have their place in a project today, or could that all be trumped by focussing on Combine and/or async/await?

üëç Yoni, Juan, Roman
Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:02:00

*Thread Reply:* Great question, thanks @Stefan. You‚Äôre 100% correct that there are a lot of ways to add concurrency to your project. It‚Äôs been a long-standing challenge to make concurrency safe and easy to understand. I hope you‚Äôll forgive my bias, but given the channel we‚Äôre in I‚Äôll say this ‚Äî async/await is the best way to use concurrency in your app. If you can use it, use that first. You‚Äôve probably seen that we‚Äôre actively improving it over time as well, with more support for Sendable this year, additional algorithms for Async Sequence, and more.

Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:03:00

*Thread Reply:* What I love most about async/await is the deep integration with the language that it provides. That allows the highest level of safety because the compiler and language can help point out places where there may have otherwise been a concurrency bug. For example, using actors to isolate state

Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:04:48

*Thread Reply:* Now, do other things still have a place today? I think the answer is yes if you‚Äôre deploying to platforms that don‚Äôt support async/await (although with back deployment and the rapid uptake of new OSes, this should hopefully be a short lived problem). Another reason is just supporting legacy code that you don‚Äôt want to refactor right away. We hope that there are enough pieces available that you can start to adopt it incrementally where possible as well

Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:05:02

*Thread Reply:* Hope that helps!

Stefan
2022-06-07 21:08:21

*Thread Reply:* Thanks a ton @Tony P (Apple), it helps yeah. I‚Äôve been diving quite deep into the new async algorithms, hence the question. I‚Äôve personally always been a fan of operations. Not just for concurrency or asynchronous tasks, but also just to plainly schedule a flow to happen in a certain order, that might be a different conversation though üòÖ . I‚Äôm excited to (hopefully soon) start incorporating these swift async algorithms.

üëç Tony P (Apple), Yoni, Patrick, XIANGXIN
Yuri A (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:02:13

‚åö This is just a reminder that we‚Äôre at the halfway mark with one hour left. We‚Äôve received great questions so far! Keep them coming!

‚ù§Ô∏è Jonathan G (Apple), Jose F (Apple), Yoni
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 21:19:26

@Amy asked > Has it been considered to have a type like instancetype that could be used as a return type for a method? Use case: methods that return self (or other instances of the same class), that subclasses could override, and the type checker would know it was an instance of the subclass. Currently working around it with generics, but that requires explicitly typing the receiving variable‚Ä¶

Jonathan G (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:23:18

*Thread Reply:* Hi Amy! I hope your WWDC is going well so far!

Generally speaking, the equivalent to instancetype in Swift is Self. For example:

```class Animal { class func adopt() -> Self { ... } }

class Dog: Animal { override class func adopt() -> Self { ... } }`` Are you running into a scenario whereSelf` isn't the right tool or isn't building? If I'm misunderstanding the issue, please let me know! üôÇ

Amy
2022-06-07 21:23:52

*Thread Reply:* Can this be used on an instance method?

Jonathan G (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:25:03

*Thread Reply:* Yes! I couldn't think of a specific example to share, but it should work with instance methods as well. You just need to drop the class specifier on the function(s).

Amy
2022-06-07 21:26:21

*Thread Reply:* The specifics: I'm porting Lexical (originally JavaScript text editor library). We have a clone-on-write pattern for our node classes. You call node.getWriteable() and it should return either the same node (if it's already writeable) or a mutable copy.

I could have sworn I investigated Self as a type, but maybe I overlooked it! I will check it out. Thanks.

Jonathan G (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:26:41

*Thread Reply:* Happy to help!

Amy
2022-06-07 21:26:51

*Thread Reply:* (If this does work, why don't the multiple foundation mutablecopy methods use it?)

David S (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:28:36

*Thread Reply:* Those are imported from ObjC, rather than written natively in Swift

Amy
2022-06-07 21:31:07

*Thread Reply:* Ah gotcha!

Jonathan G (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:32:42

*Thread Reply:* As David says. mutableCopy() is an interface into Objective-C's NSMutableCopying protocol rather than being a Swift feature. One constraint here is that mutableCopy() does not necessarily return an instance of Self‚Äîit could, for instance, return an instance of a type elsewhere in the class hierarchy. Compare copy() which often cannot return Self:

let a: NSMutableString = ... let b = a.copy() // type of `b` is `NSString`, not `NSMutableString`.

Doug G (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:33:07

*Thread Reply:* -copy and -mutableCopy in Objective-C don't use instancetype, either, because they don't fulfill the contract: -copy on an NSMutableString returns some subclass of NSString that won't necessarily by an NSMutableString. And -mutableCopy will return some NSMutableString or subclass thereof that might not be related to the NSString (or subclass) it was called from.

Jonathan G (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:33:17

*Thread Reply:* There's no generic way to express the relationship between the types of a and a.copy() in Objective-C, so id is used, and that's imported into Swift as Any.

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 21:24:53

@Edward asked > with xcode 14, > &gt; @available(iOS 15.0, **) &gt; private(set) lazy var myVar: &lt;Some type only available on iOS15.0+&gt; &gt; > gives Stored properties cannot be marked potentially unavailable with '@available' error. what is the new workaround we should use to have a stored property of a type that is only available on some versions?

Robert W (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:25:36

*Thread Reply:* The solution is generally to hide the true underlying type of the variable. One potential solution is: final class Foo { private lazy var _myBackingVar: Any { ... } @available(iOS 15.0, **) var myConditionallyAvailableVar: RealType { _myBackingVar as! RealType } }

üëÄ Edward
üëç Edward, Guillaume L (Apple), Martin
‚ùì Michael, Yoni
Karoy L (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:32:04

*Thread Reply:* Another option that is sometimes useful is to define separate types for the cases with/without the partially available stored property, and to define a protocol over them that covers common members and can hold extension methods

üëÄ Edward
üëç Edward, Rhys, Martin
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 21:38:27

@Philippe asked > I've been using RxSwift and Combine, and am starting to really like Swift Async Algorithms. Would you say that's the way forward for async sequences, superceding even Combine?

üëÄ Joshua, Mihai, Philip
Philip
2022-06-07 21:43:15

*Thread Reply:* I would like to extend the question about back pressure support üôÇ

Doug G (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:51:15

*Thread Reply:* I think the commentary in https://wwdc22.slack.com/archives/C03H0JN431U/p1654628520096709?thread_ts=1654628350.752979&cid=C03H0JN431U applies here as well: async/await and async sequences integrate really well into the language, such that we can give stronger guarantees, and it makes control flow easier to reason about. The Async Algorithms package provides a wealth of algorithms to work with async sequences.

} Tony P (Apple) (https://wwdc22.slack.com/team/U03HL5K6L04)
<p>Great question, thanks @Stefan. You‚Äôre 100% correct that there are a lot of ways to add concurrency to your project. It‚Äôs been a long-standing challenge to make concurrency safe and easy to understand. I hope you‚Äôll forgive my bias, but given the channel we‚Äôre in I‚Äôll say this ‚Äî async/await is the best way to use concurrency in your app. If you can use it, use that first. You‚Äôve probably seen that we‚Äôre actively improving it over time as well, with more support for <code>Sendable</code> this year, additional algorithms for Async Sequence, and more.</p>
Original URL: https://wwdc22.slack.com/archives/C03H0JN431U/p1654628520096709?thread_ts=1654628350.752979&amp;cid=C03H0JN431U
From a thread in <b>#devtools-and-swift-lounge</b>
Doug G (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:51:44

*Thread Reply:* For back pressure specifically, check out the Channel type within the Async Algorithms package: https://github.com/apple/swift-async-algorithms/blob/main/Sources/AsyncAlgorithms/AsyncAlgorithms.docc/Guides/Channel.md

GitHub
swift-async-algorithms/Channel.md at main ¬∑ apple/swift-async-algorithms
Async Algorithms for Swift. Contribute to apple/swift-async-algorithms development by creating an account on GitHub.

üëç Philippe
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 21:41:55

@Todd asked > First I want to thank everyone who worked on the new regex APIs. It is so Apple that you went back to first principles and asked how programming with regexes could be improved, and the result is so above and beyond what I expected! > > My question: I usually forget about lazy when writing collection code. I know in principle what it means, but I haven't gotten in the habit of using it when I should. Are there simple rules of thumb to memorize, or is it more complicated than that? How does a StdLib expert think about this topic?

David S (Apple)
2022-06-07 21:42:14

*Thread Reply:* Whether to use lazy is pretty situational, but here‚Äôs what I look for: ‚Ä¢ am I going to access the resulting collection more than once? -> probably not lazy ‚Ä¢ am I not going to access the entire collection? -> consider lazy ‚Ä¢ am I chaining multiple collection operations? -> consider lazy ‚Ä¢ do my collection operation closures have side effects? -> lazy can be dangerous here Also note that you can combine things! For example, you could do Array(someCollection.lazy.filter {‚Ä¶}.map {‚Ä¶}) to avoid some intermediate allocations but ultimately end up with the same result as if it was eager

üëç Denis
Todd
2022-06-07 21:44:12

*Thread Reply:* Thank you, this is helpful!

Jose F (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:00:55

@Luke asked > Is this trending of placing new developments into packages separate from the standard library, like async sequences and collections, going to be more common going forward? I was wondering if the aim is to allow for more frequent updates like what‚Äôs been going in the android ecosystem with the jetpack suite of libraries

Myke S (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:07:05

*Thread Reply:* BTW this question is from the previous Swift Standard Library lounge but we still wanted to answer it. üôÇ

Alejandro A (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:09:24

*Thread Reply:* Hi! We love our packages and would be more than excited to make more if it made sense as a package. Some things make more sense in the standard library and others as standalone packages. We‚Äôre also using packages to get feedback on things we‚Äôd like to eventually add to the standard library.

*Thread Reply:* Can you mix and match. If you end up making something properly good, can you then put it into Xcode if you need to add extra features?

Matt P (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:35:37

*Thread Reply:* You can open app projects created by Swift Playgrounds in Xcode!

Matt P (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:06:29

The app development features are new to Swift Playgrounds on macOS this year! Has anyone built something fun for Mac yet?

Matt
2022-06-07 22:09:31

*Thread Reply:* LOVE the update on the Mac, especially‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs brilliant for teaching and really fun for building apps you want to share over to your iPad to keep working on the go‚Ä¶

üß° Shaun C (Apple), Collett C (Apple), Matt P (Apple)
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 22:07:22

@Edward asked > is accessing the projected value publisher of a @Published variable thread safe? and does that publisher emit the current value as the first event?

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:08:23

*Thread Reply:* so to clarify the behavior of @Published - accessing the value at any time is thread safe, however the transition from the state of unsubscribed to subscribed is technically not thread safe; ideally those transitions should be bound to the main actor

üëç Edward
Myke S (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:08:43

*Thread Reply:* This question was also left over from the previous Swift StdLib lounge. üôÇ

Matt P (Apple)

2022-06-07 22:26:44

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 22:29:36

@Tyson asked > How was the debugging working in the preview? Can you tell us a little about that? Looks super helpful.

Matt P (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:29:41

*Thread Reply:* In Swift Playgrounds, the App Preview is always running, so every change you make reflects immediately and automatically! You can also use print statements, which show as message bubbles in the console.

2022-06-07 22:29:58

2022-06-07 22:31:05

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 22:30:14

@Nicholas S asked > What‚Äôs the right way to add Info.plist settings to an app? For stuff like export restrictions? >

Connor W (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:30:22

*Thread Reply:* If you edit the Package.swift inside of the project, you can add the additionalInfoPlistContentFilePath parameter to the app initializer. This is the path within the project to a file which contains additional Info.plist key-value pairs, and they'll be added to the app you build.

‚ùó Nicholas S
Nicholas S
2022-06-07 22:31:07

*Thread Reply:* Can you say more about that? I can‚Äôt find the Package.swift in playgrounds

Connor W (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:32:39

*Thread Reply:* The Package.swift file isn't visible inside of Swift Playgrounds, but if you have a Mac you can right-click it and choose "Show Package Contents" and then edit the Package.swift file from there

2022-06-07 22:31:33

2022-06-07 22:35:12

2022-06-07 22:35:52

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 22:32:23

@Nicholas S asked > Is there a way to use asset catalogs? Or a right away to include @2x and @3x assets?

Madison F (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:32:46

*Thread Reply:* Yes! Importing your first image to the app creates an asset catalog for ya. The app imports it as a universal asset. You can add the @2x & @3x assets to the project when opened in Xcode.

üëç Robert
Nicholas S
2022-06-07 22:34:01

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 22:35:24

@Dong asked > I want to use CoreData or Realm in Swift Playgrounds App project, any good suggestions? My student very like Swift Playgrounds 4.1.Because it has very fast preview and very little resource requirements on Mac.

Connor W (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:35:31

*Thread Reply:* You can use the CoreData framework by importing it, but Swift Playgrounds does not support managed object model files at this time. Please file a feedback at feedbackassistant.apple.com to request this functionality.

üëç Dong
Dong

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 22:35:55

Matt P (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:35:59

*Thread Reply:* The new app project format used by Swift Playgrounds can also be opened by Xcode directly! Does that answer your question?

Robert
2022-06-07 22:36:31

*Thread Reply:* Yes, thank you!

Andrew
2022-06-07 22:37:54

Matt P (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:38:48

Andrew
2022-06-07 22:39:40

*Thread Reply:* Thanks üôè

Robert
2022-06-07 22:44:15

*Thread Reply:* One clarification - if I open a playground inside an Xcode project, does Xcode modify the file so that it no longer works properly as a Playground document? and assuming I don't mess up the document myself, obviously. üôÇ

Matt P (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:46:33

*Thread Reply:* In general, Xcode won't make any changes to your app project that make it incompatible with Swift Playgrounds! There are some things that you could do that are only supported in Xcode, but you'll get a warning if you do any of those

‚ù§Ô∏è Robert

2022-06-07 22:50:54

2022-06-07 22:54:12

‚úÖ Matt P (Apple)
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 22:41:09

@Vladislav asked > Can swift playground handle unsupported file formats? I wanna use similar with Resource.copy(""). In this case I can manage files like CoreData Model, metal shaders files and anything I want!

Connor W (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:41:19

*Thread Reply:* Yes! If you manually edit the Package.swift file, you can set up explicit Resource.copy rules for resources which Swift Playgrounds doesn't know how to process.

üëç Eric, Dong
Vladislav
2022-06-07 22:44:30

*Thread Reply:* Great! But warning note on top said: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt change it file manually, because Package.swift is generated automatically‚Äù. Should I scare this note or Swift Playground smart enough?

Connor W (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:46:24

*Thread Reply:* You should be careful when editing the file, and making changes in the App Settings sheet may cause your edits to be lost, but generally Swift Playgrounds should preserve them.

Vladislav
2022-06-07 22:49:17

*Thread Reply:* Wow! Thats sound great!

üòÄ Dong
Vladislav
2022-06-07 22:49:23

*Thread Reply:* Thanks a lot, Connor!

If your question didn't get answered, you can check to see if there are other Developer Tools Sessions, Labs, or Lounges that might be better suited to your questions. For topics not covered there, you can also post your questions in the Developer Forums.

Also, be sure to check out the ‚ÄúYou can build an app for that!‚Äù challenge! The <#C03JPCE9ZED|> is open all day today to talk through your ideas and ask questions. Have a great rest of your WWDC!

Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:02:35

Hello! Welcome to Meet the Presenter: Meet Swift Async Algorithms. My name is Tony and I‚Äôm a manager on the Swift team at Apple. With me today is our amazing presenter Philippe, along with many other members of the Swift team.

I hope you‚Äôre all exited for the watch party! At 2:05pm PDT we‚Äôll all start the video together, so make sure you‚Äôre all set up to start with me. I‚Äôll be creating some threads as the video progresses that align with sections. Use those to talk and ask questions! When the video finishes we will have plenty of time for more in-depth Q&A.

In the meantime, here are some useful links:

Swift Async Algorithms on GitHub: https://github.com/apple/swift-async-algorithms (we use GitHub Issues and Pull Requests)
Swift Async Algorithms on the Swift Forums: https://forums.swift.org/c/related-projects/swift-async-algorithms/

Set your new Swift Clock for a 5 minute countdown...

Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:04:18

Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/110355/
ü•≥ Cristian-Mihai, Stefan, Edward, Fernando, Myke S (Apple), Jens, Johan, Kwanghoon
Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:05:06

Are you ready? Press play in 3... 2... 1... go!

Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:05:12

üì∫

Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:07:34

Multi-input Algorithms üßµ

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:07:55

*Thread Reply:* These are things like merge, zip, or combineLatest

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:08:15

*Thread Reply:* all things that take multiple input AsyncSequences and produce one output

Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:11:10

Clock, instant, duration üßµ

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:12:06

*Thread Reply:* These are standard library primitives for sleeping tasks and gathering information on the time of execution

Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:13:28

Algorithms using time üßµ

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:14:40

*Thread Reply:* These are AsyncSequences that do things like rate limiting. Like debounce or throttle.

Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:15:10

Chunks! üßµ

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:16:05

*Thread Reply:* These AsyncSequences up into collections of values by certain methods or combinations of those methods.

Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:16:15

Collections üßµ

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:17:05

*Thread Reply:* The collection initializers let you create common collection types with AsyncSequences so you can use them later or with existing code.

üôå Robert
Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:18:18

That‚Äôs a wrap üì¶ !

Thanks for watching everyone! We‚Äôre not done yet, though -- let‚Äôs use the rest of the time here for more detailed Q&A. Feel free to use that ‚ÄòAsk a Question‚Äô workflow and we‚Äôll keep everything organized in threads. Let‚Äôs go!

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 23:20:38

@Vladislav asked > Why AsyncStream can't use multiple subscribers? Swift crashed with unstopped task error. I wanna see same result as in Combine Publisher.

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:21:37

*Thread Reply:* That got changed in swift 5.7: originally the problem was that the case that multiple consumers was undefined behavior, but we refined that to now allow for multiple consumers. But note: each consumer will consume the iteration independently so they will not share the values.

Vladislav
2022-06-07 23:23:03

*Thread Reply:* Sound great! I will wait Swift 5.7.

P.S. Your hair color is great!

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:23:46

*Thread Reply:* thanks!

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:24:31

*Thread Reply:* Note: if you are using an AsyncStream pre 5.7 you have nothing to worry about if the stream is used just by one task

üëç Vladislav
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 23:21:45

@Edward asked > Are these new algorithms compatible with earlier versions of iOS?

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:22:17

*Thread Reply:* A good amount of them can be used before the most recent releases; the ones that use time need OS level support to do it

üôå Edward
Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:22:36

*Thread Reply:* so for example zip can be used as far back as Swift concurrency can

üëç Roman, Edward
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 23:25:04

@Chen-Yu asked > What would be Combine's place with Swift concurrency now released? How to choose between the two? Will Combine be mainly used behind the scenes for SwiftUI only?

üëç Juan, Roman, Eric, Jens, William, omar
Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:25:32

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the question @Chen-Yu ‚Äî we actually talked about this a bit earlier today over here, which I think answers it: https://wwdc22.slack.com/archives/C03H0JN431U/p1654628520096709?thread_ts=1654628350.752979&cid=C03H0JN431U

} Tony P (Apple) (https://wwdc22.slack.com/team/U03HL5K6L04)
<p>Great question, thanks @Stefan. You‚Äôre 100% correct that there are a lot of ways to add concurrency to your project. It‚Äôs been a long-standing challenge to make concurrency safe and easy to understand. I hope you‚Äôll forgive my bias, but given the channel we‚Äôre in I‚Äôll say this ‚Äî async/await is the best way to use concurrency in your app. If you can use it, use that first. You‚Äôve probably seen that we‚Äôre actively improving it over time as well, with more support for <code>Sendable</code> this year, additional algorithms for Async Sequence, and more.</p>
Original URL: https://wwdc22.slack.com/archives/C03H0JN431U/p1654628520096709?thread_ts=1654628350.752979&amp;cid=C03H0JN431U
From a thread in <b>#devtools-and-swift-lounge</b>
üôå Robert
Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:26:45

*Thread Reply:* To add a bit more about Combine specifically, we think that the AsyncSequence-based API in Async Algorithms, deeply integrating into the language support, is going to be the best way to use these algorithms

üëå Chen-Yu, Joseph
üëç Edward, Roman, Benjamin
üôå Robert, Eric
ü§ó Stefan
Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:27:22

*Thread Reply:* I talked a bit about it here too: https://www.swift.org/blog/swift-async-algorithms/

Swift.org
Introducing Swift Async Algorithms
As part of Swift‚Äôs move toward safe, simple, and performant asynchronous programming, we are pleased to introduce a new package of algorithms for AsyncSequence. It is called Swift Async Algorithms and it is available now on GitHub.
Original URL: https://www.swift.org/blog/swift-async-algorithms/
üôå Robert
üëç Juan
Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:28:12

*Thread Reply:* Another big bonus: Async Algorithms is open source and cross-platform

ü§© Stefan, Eric, Konrad M (Apple)
‚ù§Ô∏è Roman, Joseph, Adrian, Konrad M (Apple)
Adrien
2022-06-07 23:49:35

*Thread Reply:* But does Async Algorithms provide an equivalent to @Published/CurrentValueSubject, i.e. a way to do state observation?

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:55:01

*Thread Reply:* There isnt a property wrapper for changes in AsyncAlgorithms but there is a thing similar to subjects

Tony P (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:55:41

*Thread Reply:* Specifically for SwiftUI, those remain the way to notify views of state that needs to change

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:56:36

*Thread Reply:* the thing similar to subjects is AsyncChannel . That is a way to send values between tasks. But as Tony points out for the SwiftUI side of things ObservableObject and @Published are good ways to still communicate events.

üôè Adrien, Artyom
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 23:29:24

@Shawn asked > Does the new Swift Package give us anything akin to a Parallel For-Loop?

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:30:10

*Thread Reply:* This package does not have a way to do that because swift concurrency already has a pretty good tool to do it already: withTaskGroup - that allows parallel iteration and manages the lifetime of that iteration accordingly

Shawn
2022-06-07 23:30:52

*Thread Reply:* That's good to know thanks!

Aura Lily V (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:30:53

*Thread Reply:* The docs for it are at https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swift/withtaskgroup(of:returning:body:) if you‚Äôre interested.

Aura Lily V (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:31:24

*Thread Reply:* Bonus: this is part of the base async/await implementation, so it works with iOS 15 and Big Sur üôÇ

üëè Shawn
Aura Lily V (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:31:46

*Thread Reply:* all the way back to 10.15 and iOS 13, actually, thanks to back-deployment.

Jonathan
2022-06-07 23:34:10

*Thread Reply:* You can look at https://github.com/JohnSundell/CollectionConcurrencyKit if you want examples of parallel collection operations.

Jonathan
2022-06-07 23:34:28

*Thread Reply:* Also note that withTaskGroup may not perform well for large collections in the Swift 5.5 runtime IIRC.

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 23:33:04

@Kai asked > What are ways to define async work that returns an AsyncSequence, which is lazy. So it only runs later when explicitly requested or started?

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:33:41

*Thread Reply:* AsyncSequences are by nature very similar to lazy algorithms because they process things via their next function of their iterators

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:34:11

*Thread Reply:* so that first call to next is that request for things to be done; and that function is mutating so that it can know if it has started or not

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 23:56:57

@Derik asked > I‚Äôm struggling to grasp what is go on behind the scenes during an await for an AsyncSequence like in your examples from today‚Äôs session with Zip and Merge. Could you show an example similar to those on how to build an AsyncSequence that can take advantage of these new algorithms?

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:58:14

*Thread Reply:* So AsyncSequence is nothing more than just a fancy way of having multiple await calls to a single function; next. Those awaits are suspension points for the concurrency runtime to say; hey suspend here and go potentially do work somewhere else and resume me when you have something

üëç Derik
üíö Derik, Artyom
Derik
2022-06-07 23:59:33

*Thread Reply:* Is there an example somewhere I could reference? In the docs or somewhere else?

Aura Lily V (Apple)
2022-06-07 23:59:57

*Thread Reply:* There‚Äôs some discussion up at https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swift/asyncsequence

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:00:07

*Thread Reply:* we have a ton of documentation on each algorithm; https://github.com/apple/swift-async-algorithms/tree/main/Sources/AsyncAlgorithms/AsyncAlgorithms.docc/Guides

GitHub
swift-async-algorithms/Sources/AsyncAlgorithms/AsyncAlgorithms.docc/Guides at main ¬∑ apple/swift-async-algorithms
Async Algorithms for Swift. Contribute to apple/swift-async-algorithms development by creating an account on GitHub.
Original URL: https://github.com/apple/swift-async-algorithms/tree/main/Sources/AsyncAlgorithms/AsyncAlgorithms.docc/Guides
Derik
2022-06-08 00:00:07

*Thread Reply:* Like an example of setting up the next for the primaryAccount.messages

Image from iOS
Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:00:43

*Thread Reply:* ah so the bases in that example are AsyncStream

üëç Derik
Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:01:05

*Thread Reply:* https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swift/asyncstream/

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:01:20

*Thread Reply:* but they could be anything

Aura Lily V (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:03:39

*Thread Reply:* Building an async sequence from scratch may or may not be trivial ‚Äî starting is not very hard, as all you need to do is to build a type that conforms to AsyncSequence, but coordinating with asynchronous processes can be a little difficult. AsyncStream is a very easy way to take a traditional, callback-based or delegate-based asynchronous process and make repeated results available as a ready-made async sequence that does that work for you.

Aura Lily V (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:04:03

*Thread Reply:* This package exists so that the more complicated cases ‚Äî the more complicated implementations of next() ‚Äî are handled for you, and you need only combine them üôÇ

Aura Lily V (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:04:27

*Thread Reply:* Thankfully, if you‚Äôre curious, it‚Äôs open source ‚Äî just look at the GitHub link above üôÇ

üëç Derik
Derik
2022-06-08 00:06:39

*Thread Reply:* Oh I see so with AsyncStream it's basically a collection of continuations.

Aura Lily V (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:06:57

*Thread Reply:* Well, just the one, but it can be invoked repeatedly.

Derik
2022-06-08 00:09:16

*Thread Reply:* That quake example reminds me of subscribing to a combine Future.

Derik
2022-06-08 00:23:19

*Thread Reply:* So basically to make an AsyncSequence you create a struct that wraps a struct that conforms to the AsyncIteratorProtocol that provides the mutating func next() async function that performs some asynchronous action and returns the expected Element?

Aura Lily V (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:23:55

*Thread Reply:* Correct üôÇ

Aura Lily V (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:24:16

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôll be moving on from this lounge to give space to the new topic ‚Äî but you got the gist of it.

Derik
2022-06-08 00:26:03

*Thread Reply:* Thank you

Hi! We‚Äôre ready to start the C, C++, Objective-C compiler, analyzer, sanitizer, debugger, and linker Q&A. We have a number of engineers here that work on build tools to answer your questions. Submit your questions with the :workflowbolt: button below. We will review your questions and then post them here for everyone to see.

We might not be able to get to all of your questions but we‚Äôll do our best. As a reminder, please keep the content professional and within our code of conduct.

If you have questions on other topics, you can check to see if there are other Developer Tools Sessions, Labs, or Lounges that might be better suited to your questions. For topics not covered there, you can also post your questions in the Developer Forums.
