DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 00:11:22

@Miguel asked > Hello Everybody! > Why XCode 14 is deprecating the use of bitcode? Is it will be enabled automatically?

Myke S (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:11:39

*Thread Reply:* Yes, that is correct. We announced bitcode deprecation in the <https://developer.apple.com/go/?id=xcode-14-sdk-rn |Xcode 14 Release Notes>. We can't comment on those decisions but do you have any particular concerns around this deprecation or are you seeing any issues that we can help you work through?

Myke S (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:12:29

*Thread Reply:* If your project contains bitcode, you will get a warning message asking you to remove it. IPAs that contain bitcode will have the bitcode stripped before being submitted to the App Store.

Myke S (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:12:46

*Thread Reply:* @Steven asked a similar question so tagging them so they see this.

Steven
2022-06-08 00:13:40

*Thread Reply:* No concerns from my side, part of my curiosity also ties into some of those issues that were present in older version of Xcode with back-deployed swift concurrency.

Miguel
2022-06-08 00:16:03

*Thread Reply:* No concerns either, I knew that bitcode optimizes the size of our application and deliver only the necessary elements to a specific device, but if it will be considered by default I don't have any worries

Andrew
2022-06-08 00:16:26

*Thread Reply:* üòÄ I got burned by that swift concurrency bug, utterly unintentionally because a Realm update linked it in. My app was broken for iOS13 & 14 for 2 months until I found out!

> IPAs that contain bitcode will have the bitcode stripped before being submitted to the App Store. Are we strongly encouraged to remove bitcode settings rather than relying on this?

Myke S (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:17:25

*Thread Reply:* @Miguel - Bitcode is actually not needed for "app thinning" which is what you're talking about. We will continue to produce different versions of your app with only the necessary architectures and resources on the Store side.

‚úÖ Andrew, Alexander, Ashton
üíØ Miguel
Steven
2022-06-08 00:18:08

*Thread Reply:* to @Andrew's point there, with supporting Swift concurrency I would probably want to tell our customers to not enable bitcode regardless. I imagine the bitcode stripping would occur regardless of Xcode version since it's probably happening store side?

Myke S (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:18:37

*Thread Reply:* @Andrew at some point in the future, we will remove the option for you so yes, might as well just turn it off now. If there's some reason why you need to have it turned on, we'd love to know more.

Myke S (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:19:42

*Thread Reply:* Bitcode stripping happens on the client side with Xcode 14. If you are submitting your app with an older version of Xcode, you can continue to submit bitcode. But at some point, those SDKs will no longer be supported and you will need to update your Xcode.

‚ù§Ô∏è Steven
üëç Andrew, Kenneth
Steven
2022-06-08 00:20:04

*Thread Reply:* Thank you for that clarification

*Thread Reply:* The above errors you posted are dyld (dynamic loader) errors. So if we go back to the idea of comparing the 2 projects: large existing, with error vs. new, from template, that works.

2022-06-08 00:36:21

Julian L (Apple)

*Thread Reply:* Ideally, we could somehow find a way to reduce the larger project until it works (and then investigate the step that triggers the change), or go from the other way: make the empty project more and more complicated to resemble your project until it fails.

Michael
2022-06-08 00:38:35

*Thread Reply:* Unfortunately, there is no good way to remove individual elements from the project, because of interdependencies.

Julian L (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:39:07

*Thread Reply:* Can we go from the other way; complicating the empty project until it resembles the existing one?

Julian L (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:40:05

*Thread Reply:* This is a macOS app, correct?

Michael
2022-06-08 00:41:04

*Thread Reply:* Perhaps, but not easily. My executable is 2.28 GB with both ASAN and UBSAN turned on, so it would take some doing to generate that much code. Yes, macOS.

Michael
2022-06-08 00:41:23

*Thread Reply:* LD_RUNPATH_SEARCH_PATHS = $(inherited) @executable_path/../Frameworks

Michael
2022-06-08 00:42:55

*Thread Reply:* Not seeing anything else that is non-default

Michael
2022-06-08 00:43:46

*Thread Reply:* I was thinking screen share is the path of least resistance.

Julian L (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:45:22

*Thread Reply:* (I am not a dyld/linker person, but it seems LD_RUNPATH_SEARCH_PATHS might be an old setting.)

Julian L (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:47:17

*Thread Reply:* In the above error message it says that we fail to find/load Accelerate.framework.

Julian L (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:48:14

*Thread Reply:* Maybe setting DYLD_FRAMEWORK_PATH can help here.

Michael
2022-06-08 00:48:33

*Thread Reply:* Yes. But it is looking in the right place for it. Accelerate.framework lives in the dyldsharedcache as of Monterey. And also, it works with only ASAN or only UBSAN or with neither.

Julian L (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:49:12

*Thread Reply:* That's a good point and lends more credence to the "binary too big" theory.

üëç Michael
Julian L (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:50:19

*Thread Reply:* So then our working theory is that this fails, because the instrumented code is too big. ü§î

dyld cache '/System/Library/dyld/dyld_shared_cache_arm64e' not loaded: syscall to map cache into shared region failed

Michael
2022-06-08 00:51:04

*Thread Reply:* That was my initial guess, but as you saw in the FB, it was ruled out. Maybe it shouldn‚Äôt have been?

Julian L (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:51:13

*Thread Reply:* I know we have suggested this before: any chance we can reduce the size of the project, to verify/give us another data points there.

Michael
2022-06-08 00:52:07

*Thread Reply:* To be clear, we need to reduce the size of the executable which dyld is mapping, right? Just tossing out resources, for example, wouldn‚Äôt really help.

Julian L (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:52:56

*Thread Reply:* That's my understanding, yes.

Michael
2022-06-08 00:53:25

*Thread Reply:* I could try building it as Release configuration instead of Debug configuration. That might slim it down enough to make a difference.

üëç Julian L (Apple)
Michael
2022-06-08 00:55:49

*Thread Reply:* Building now, but it will take a while. I‚Äôll update here when I‚Äôm able to try it.

Julian L (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:00:58

*Thread Reply:* Sounds good. One more angle of attack would be to observe what dyld is doing and compare between "ASan only" and "ASan & UBSan", e.g., by using the DYLD_PRINT_LIBRARIES=1 environment variable.

Julian L (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:01:17

*Thread Reply:* See the dyld man pages: man dyld

Michael
2022-06-08 01:03:42

*Thread Reply:* OK, I can collect that too. Each variant requires a rebuild which might take more time than is available in this session.

Michael
2022-06-08 01:12:17

*Thread Reply:* Release build with ASAN + UBSAN launches. Executable size is 813.5 MB

üéâ Julian L (Apple)
Julian L (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:12:56

*Thread Reply:* I connected with the dyld team and they confirmed that binary size can indeed be a problem and most likely is the culprit here! Unfortunately, we don't have a way to "fix" this in the short term.

The suggested workarounds are: ‚Ä¢ If possible, you could move some of your code into a **.dylib to split up the large executable. ‚Ä¢ (Keep what you are doing right now:) Use ASan/UBSan separately ‚Ä¢ Use Release for testing with sanitizer/CI

Julian L (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:15:33

*Thread Reply:* I've associated your feedback ticket to our internal ticket that tracks the underlying issue. You should be notified via the Feedback website if this issue is resolved.

Michael
2022-06-08 01:17:13

*Thread Reply:* OK, thanks for checking into that! It makes me feel like the world makes sense again. üôÇ We currently do separate Debug CI builds for ASAN and UBSAN, and run them against our test suite. It is just for those individual developers who like to run with both options turned on all the time, that I am investigating. I have signed up for the Thursday lab, so I will follow up there in case someone from Apple wants to confirm with the actual project.

üëç Julian L (Apple)
Julian L (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:18:28

*Thread Reply:* Also to keep in mind: in case your binary grows, the "ASan only" version might run into the same issue in the future.

Michael
2022-06-08 01:19:14

*Thread Reply:* Maybe I‚Äôll be retired by then! üòÄ

üòÜ Julian L (Apple)

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 00:25:58

@Juan Martell asked > Hello, does using optimization level (e.g. [-Oz]) generate any negative impact on the performance of the app?

Michael S (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:26:13

*Thread Reply:* Different optimization levels have different tradeoffs they attempt to make, but the compiler can‚Äôt know precisely the impact that a given optimization decision will have. In general -Oz will trade runtime performance for codesize when the two are in opposition, but still generates faster code than -O0 or -O1 (in rare cases even faster than -O2 or -O3). The default (-Os) is usually best, but the optimization level can affect both size and performance. Benchmarking with your app is the best way to know for sure. You can use Instruments to analyze the performance of your app and compare multiple optimization levels.

Miguel
2022-06-08 00:35:33

*Thread Reply:* Do you recommend to set (-Os) in Apple Clang and (-Osize) in Swift Compiler to make a difference in the size of application?

Adrian P (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:37:04

*Thread Reply:* On Apple platforms -Os is the default optimization level.

Miguel
2022-06-08 00:41:44

*Thread Reply:* Thank you!

Juan Martell
2022-06-08 00:43:12

*Thread Reply:* And using Asset Catalog Compiler - Options (space) what is the impact in the assets quality? Thank you.

Adrian P (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:52:55

*Thread Reply:* This question might be better suited for the Interface Builder Lab (Jun 10, 9am).

Juan Martell
2022-06-08 01:04:45

*Thread Reply:* Thank you,

Sridhar G (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:55:55

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 01:38:05

@jerry asked > Hey all, congrats on shipping and thanks for all the great code and features! I'm working to compile clang PCMs in a remote build system and consume them in Xcode tooling. Do you have any pro tops for how to compile PCMS for the Apple SDKs in Xcode? Currently seems like the dependency graph needs to be generated for these SDKs. Any suggestions here would be appreciated

Michael S (Apple)
2022-06-08 01:38:31

*Thread Reply:* You can explicitly compile Clang modules by using the internal -cc1 command line and various flags. You would need to discover the module build graph to know which modules are needed when building each module and for the final translation unit. Explicitly building modules this way is not supported by Xcode or the various platform SDKs and will likely not work in all cases.

üôå jerry
jerry
2022-06-08 01:56:54

*Thread Reply:* Hey @Michael S (Apple) - cool, thanks for sharing! Awesome, yep I'm looking into the tooling side of it as well. It looks like it will be a fine dance to make this work end to end. We're attempting to try and make all paths in the PCMs relative. Do you suggest this or use chroot?

Michael S (Apple)
2022-06-08 02:00:59

*Thread Reply:* Making the paths the same everywhere is going to work much better, there are lots of paths that show up in modules.

jerry
2022-06-08 02:05:51

*Thread Reply:* Ok cool, thanks for the tip! I'll give it a try

2022-06-08 18:09:44

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 18:23:00

@mike asked > Is there a way to disable/workaround the need for public qualifiers on classes/funcs in the Source folder? Often I pull a swift class out of an existing project to experiment against it, and end up having to change this.

Connor W (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:28:44

*Thread Reply:* It is not possible to disable access control for separate modules, including the module created for sources in the Sources folder of a playground.

Swift Playgrounds supports creating app projects, which you can do by creating a new "app" instead of a new "playground" using the button at the bottom-left of the document browser. In an app project, by default all sources are part of a single module, so you don't need to use public to make things visible. App projects are also great for experimentation thanks to the live SwiftUI previews!

‚úÖ mike, Mayra M, Matt, Michael
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 18:29:50

@Matthew asked > Hi y‚Äôall! First of all, thanks so much for your work on Swift Playgrounds, especially the latest ability to make apps! > > Are there recommendations for being able to sync user data across different devices from within an app? Like a Swift Playgrounds app creating a list of objects that would automatically go to Mac, iPad, and iPhone

üëç Nikhil
Jonathan P (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:30:34

*Thread Reply:* Some services (like CloudKit) are not supported in app projects at this time. But you can use UIDocumentPickerViewController to ask the user to pick a folder in iCloud drive. Save a bookmark of the folder's file URL and you will have sandbox permissions to read and write to that folder whenever you want. Then it will be synced over iCloud Drive.

Matthew
2022-06-08 18:35:20

*Thread Reply:* Oooo, really cool idea

üôÇ Jonathan P (Apple)
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 18:31:05

@Mayra M asked > Hello! Question about how to build ‚Äúguided instructional content‚Äù. Where is that done: Swift Playgrounds, or Xcode? Thanks!

Marcus J (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:31:37

*Thread Reply:* You can build guided content in either Swift Playgrounds or Xcode! If you do want to edit your guided content on Playgrounds, make sure to turn on Authoring Debug Mode in the app's settings. To see how our team writes content, check out https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/110349/

Apple Developer
Create engaging content for Swift Playgrounds - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
Learn how you can build guided instructional content designed for Swift Playgrounds. Follow along with us as we explore how you can add a...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/110349/
Mayra M
2022-06-08 18:33:31

*Thread Reply:* Thank you for your reply! I managed to watch half of your talk, then raced to the lounge. In the older Playgrounds you could get in trouble when trying to use Markup‚Äôs invisible writing (the moment you closed the line it would vanish!). Has that been taken care of?

Marcus J (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:41:33

*Thread Reply:* App projects no longer use the hidden code block syntax that was available in playground books. All code in a source file is visible to learners. The only thing that is hidden is the code comments used to mark walkthrough and experiments

Mayra M
2022-06-08 18:45:01

*Thread Reply:* Thanks! And thanks for mentioning ‚Äúcode comments‚Äù: could not remember the correct terms! Do you just type the code comments in Playgrounds? I could never wrap my head around using Markup (without losing the content!).

Marcus J (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:52:34

*Thread Reply:* You can totally type them in on playgrounds! Just make sure you've entered the id before closing the comment **/ for walkthroughs and ) for experiments. If you do forget to add the ID before closing the comment, you can open the project in xcode and make that change there

Mayra M
2022-06-08 18:56:56

*Thread Reply:* Apologies: ‚Äúentered the id‚Äù?

Mayra M
2022-06-08 18:58:03

*Thread Reply:* Do you mean something like /#-code-walkthrough(filename.swift)/ ?

Mayra M
2022-06-08 18:58:44

*Thread Reply:* (It ‚Äúate‚Äù the asterisks before and after the ‚Äú/‚Äú‚Ä¶ I guess that‚Äôs Markup rendering?

Marcus J (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:05:16

*Thread Reply:* Sorry if I didn't explain that well. The id that goes in the comment should match the id of a page in your walkthrough task. You can see an example of that in our session video. When writing the comment in playgrounds write /**#-code-walkthrough(id) part first before writing the **/ part just to make sure the comment doesn't disappear before you're done editing it

Marcus J (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:06:27

*Thread Reply:* It also sounds like you might be running into issues with the comments being partially hidden at the wrong times. If that is the case please file a feedback request so my team and I can look into it

Mayra M
2022-06-08 19:10:11

*Thread Reply:* Thank you! I will try and see where things go. Have a good afternoon!

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 18:38:20

@Mayra M asked > In previous versions of Playgrounds, touching the ‚ÄúAdvanced‚Äù menu would take you to a menu to access ‚ÄúView Auxiliary Source Files‚Äù. From there you had access to the **.playgroundbook file, and the Chapters/UserModules. Is there anything similar in these educational content files? Thanks.

Bryan P (Apple)
2022-06-08 18:40:53

*Thread Reply:* Unlike Playground books, app projects show all their files in the source directory in the sidebar. In the case of an app project with guided learning content, the Guide directory can be made available in the sidebar as well by enabling the Authoring Debug switch in Playgrounds settings.

Mayra M
2022-06-08 18:42:42

2022-06-08 19:48:10

@Adrian asked > Do you have any tips or recommendations for improving the reliability & performance of LLDB? Anything in particular to watch out for? In my project, it sometimes takes up to 30-40 seconds (on M1 Max!) between pausing on a breakpoint and LLDB becoming responsive.

Michal
2022-06-08 20:20:40

*Thread Reply:* This, imagine still having an Intel Mac! üòÖ

Dave L (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:22:55

*Thread Reply:* We've worked to improve the performance of lldb in Xcode 14 when debugging Swift. Please try Xcode 14 and file a feedback if the performance is an issue. From there we can get profiling data and figure out the root cause.

There's also the opportunity to 1:1 on this. I'd suggest <https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/labs-and-lounges/dashboard/upcoming?q=C%2B%2B |making an appointment for a lab>. We have a C, C++, Objective-C compiler, analyzer, sanitizer, debugger, and linker lab tomorrow which would be great.

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 20:24:10

@Jonathan asked > I have (or rather a dependency has) an Obj-C type which has a core definition and many categories spread amongst many files. Xcode's new build visualizer shows this type can take many seconds to compile (at least when integrated through SPM). Is there any way to speed it up? (https://github.com/google/promises/tree/master/Sources/FBLPromises)|https://github.com/google/promises/tree/master/Sources/FBLPromises)

Zoe C (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:25:41

*Thread Reply:* You mention SPM, so I want to clarify: are you talking about clang build times or Swift build times? Assuming that you are talking about clang build times, enabling modules for your project may improve build times (and it looks like there is already a clang module map for this library).

Jonathan
2022-06-08 20:26:43

*Thread Reply:* This is an Obj-C framework integrated through SPM, so it presumably uses SPM's build system to call clang during builds.

Jonathan
2022-06-08 20:27:19

*Thread Reply:* According to the build log, that single library takes 5 seconds to build.

Jonathan
2022-06-08 20:27:59

*Thread Reply:* On an M1 Ultra.

Jonathan
2022-06-08 20:28:33

*Thread Reply:* Unfortunately the logs don't offer any additional detail as to why it's taking that long, but I wonder if the category usage might be part of it.

Zoe C (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:29:56

*Thread Reply:* And this is just a dependency that you are using? Is the dependency getting re-built every time? I would expect that it would only be built once and then Swift could use the cached/already-built clang module.

Jonathan
2022-06-08 20:31:12

*Thread Reply:* Right, and that works. However, clean builds are used when switching branches and on CI, so I'm optimizing for those cases. For something so simple this seems a disproportionate amount of time.

Jonathan
2022-06-08 20:31:35

*Thread Reply:* Obj-C's supposed to be fast! üòÜ

‚ù§Ô∏è Michal

2022-06-08 20:36:52

Jonathan
2022-06-08 20:39:40

*Thread Reply:* Hard to tell, previous versions of Xcode didn't have the visualizer. And Xcode 14 seems to have broken my ability to open this project in 13, so just a minute.

2022-06-08 20:45:22

Steven W (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:45:52

*Thread Reply:* From my observation, SPM is using modules by default already. With the modules on, it should perform relatively good even the declarations of the categories are over lots of headers. But do note module build might sequentialize the module generation in the beginning of a clean build, so it might not scale as well with the core count (since you are on a M1 Ultra)

*Thread Reply:* Well, I can't tell what's going on. What seems to happen is that, since all of these files are interdependent, they all get batched and timed together, even though the total build time for the batch is longer than it should be. So most of the files are shown as taking the time of the whole batch to build. Sometimes (seemingly after most cleans) this batch is broken up so some of these dependent files aren't built soon enough, so the overall build time for some files is huge. It doesn't just happen to this library, it's just most visible. But I can't tell why some files are charged for their batch while others aren't, or what is causing my build time regressions on clean builds. Having to constantly reset my packages isn't helping either.

Steven W (Apple)

Michal
2022-06-08 22:13:36

*Thread Reply:* Not sure how viable would that be for your use case, but I'd also try integrating the dependency (as maybe all external ones) as a binary package ‚Äì we've been on that path for some time already & having an option to skip building Facebook, Firebase & other SDKs on different steps (mainly CI where time is really precious) is really a great helper.

At this point, it's not easy to manage local Swift packages referencing to binary artifacts (worked fine since Xcode 12.5 & 13.x) a bit hacky way, yet it's impossible at this point in Xcode 14, so the only option is fetching it from remote ‚Äì that means hosting it on your GitHub/GitLab organisation, just a repo with Package.swift file referencing the binary stored in Releases/Packages/wherever you choose. üëç

If it's possible, I'd like to talk about the local binary package issue with some dev, hopefully I'll catch a proper session here. üòÑ

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 20:44:48

@Steven asked > What if the build timeline shows unusually long compile times for a source file when building an app target containing the subtarget, but building the subtarget alone is appropriately fast?

Ben L (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:44:56

*Thread Reply:* Here are a couple of suggestions for things to look for ‚Ä¢ Could the increased time when built with the rest of the app be related to higher overall system resource contention during the build? You could try to isolate this by copying the command-line used to build the file from the Build Log in the Report Navigator, and executing just that command in Terminal with the time utility. ‚Ä¢ It's possible that slightly different command-line arguments could have been used when building the file. You could look in the Build Log in the Report Navigator for the two different builds and find the file that took a variable amount of time. Are the commands identical, or are there differences in the command-line arguments?

Steven
2022-06-08 20:48:06

*Thread Reply:* Can resource contention really block a 200 line file for ~22s?

Ben L (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:50:16

*Thread Reply:* It's possible, but if that is significantly slower than building the target in isolation and the overall machine still seems responsive during this time you could start with the other suggestion to compare compiler arguments.

Steven
2022-06-08 20:50:43

*Thread Reply:* For supertarget = ~22s, alone = ~0.1s

Steven
2022-06-08 20:50:57

*Thread Reply:* Comparing arguments now

üëç Ben L (Apple)
Steven
2022-06-08 20:55:10

*Thread Reply:* Looks like the supertarget adds another -I, and -ivfsoverlay with a yaml file

2022-06-08 20:55:12

2022-06-08 20:55:25

*Thread Reply:* Right click on a line in the build log

Steven

Ben L (Apple)
2022-06-08 21:18:37

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for following up!

It would be good to capture this issue in a Feedback report, where we can investigate in more depth what is going on. Here are some details that would be helpful to include in the Feedback ‚Ä¢ The Build Logs (showing the exact command-line arguments) and the build timelines for the two builds that differ ‚Ä¢ Your findings RE: precompiled headers ‚Ä¢ If you can capture a spindump while the slow compilation is happening (E.g. Activity Monitor > Select Process > Spindump) ‚Ä¢ If possible, attaching the project that reproduced the issue (I understand this is not always possible).

Steven
2022-06-08 21:24:25

*Thread Reply:* @Ben L (Apple) Should this be happening?

PCHs.png
Ben L (Apple)
2022-06-08 21:26:02

*Thread Reply:* Not sure what you mean - if you disabled "Precompile Prefix Header" for the target, then no.

Steven
2022-06-08 21:26:27

*Thread Reply:* I'm referring to the multiple precompiles in a single pass for a single target

Ben L (Apple)
2022-06-08 21:30:38

*Thread Reply:* I believe that happens when the same prefix header is used from files that require different compiler arguments that would affect how the PCH is built. For example, if you create a .m file and .cpp file in the same target, they require separate builds of the precompiled header

Steven
2022-06-08 21:31:02

*Thread Reply:* I see, so if we have ARC and MRR, those are separate

Steven
2022-06-08 21:31:07

*Thread Reply:* I wonder what the third is

Steven
2022-06-08 21:31:14

*Thread Reply:* thanks again

Ben L (Apple)
2022-06-08 21:32:27

*Thread Reply:* Correct, -fobjc-arc will affect how the PCH is built, so it needs to build it twice

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 20:45:04

@Nikhil asked > We Are working which is quite old. It has combination of objective c , c ++, Swift and even Swift ui now. It had good compile time on Xcode 12. But performance has really degraded with Xcode 13. I have actually stopped indexing of project. I have using m1 MacBook Pro with 16 G-Block memory. It there something u can suggest which will help us in reducing our compile time. We also use git for version control.

Argyrios K (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:45:40

*Thread Reply:* Xcode 14 includes a new build time visualizer for build logs that focuses on parallelism to help identify build performance issues. To view it go to the build log of your project, then select ‚ÄòXcode menu -> Editor -> Assistant‚Äô; this should give you detailed information about where the time is spent during a build.

It is also useful to try your project with Xcode 14 to see if the build performance has improved on your project, since Xcode 14 also includes build improvements.

üëç Nikhil
Nikhil
2022-06-08 20:52:10

*Thread Reply:* I have downloaded beta version of Xcode 14. I will check that out for sure.thanks

*Thread Reply:* Click it again, it sometimes doesn't load it immediately.

Argyrios K (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:57:54

*Thread Reply:* also note clicking on an individual entry in the build log makes the visualizer to jump there, but if the entry is not included in the visualizer then you see ‚Äúno results‚Äù. Try clicking on the top ‚ÄúPrepare build‚Äù entry

Jonathan
2022-06-08 21:05:10

*Thread Reply:* It works like the Instruments graphs.

Andrew
2022-06-08 21:05:34

*Thread Reply:* Some general strategies, having gone through the same on a large project: ‚Ä¢ Reduce Objective-C importing -Swift.h header ‚Ä¢ Create Objective-C shims for Swift classes, so if you have Swift code used in a lot of Objective-C you only import the Objective-C shim rather than the Swift header ‚Ä¢ Reduce Objective-C in your bridging header

Matt
2022-06-08 21:06:42

*Thread Reply:* Option scrollüëçI was thinking of shrinking vertically too.

Nikhil
2022-06-08 21:08:31

Argyrios K (Apple)
2022-06-08 21:12:18

*Thread Reply:* Glad to help! For related build performance issues with Xcode 14 I highly recommend filing feedback reports that include build visualizations, so we can follow-up with you with the specifics of your project.

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 21:12:58

@Maciej asked > Are this year's linking improvements related to Swift-only codebases or should we see observe reduced linking time in mixed codebases (including objc++/c++) as well?

üëç Luca, Michal
Louis G (Apple)
2022-06-08 21:17:18

*Thread Reply:* The build time performance improvements in linking this year are mostly language independent, so you should see improvement in mixed codebases. The exact improvement will depend on the structure of your code. In particular, the way you use static libraries may greatly impact how much of an improvement you see.

The runtime dynamic linker improvements this year focus on Swift, but if you build with a new enough deployment target to take advantage of page in linking you should see some improvements for all types of code.

For more info please check out this years talk: https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/110362

Apple Developer
Link fast: Improve build and launch times - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
Discover how to improve your app's build and runtime linking performance. We'll take you behind the scenes to learn more about linking,...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/110362
üëç Nikhil, Maciej
üôå Maciej
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 21:16:51

@Mikko asked > Are there any improvements to PCH generation/use? It kind of looks like the clang pch don‚Äôt quite instantiate templates when generating them, so adding templates code to pch tends to pessimise build times. The performance profile is quite different compared to $COMPILER. > > Is the build time visualiser based on -ftime-report, or is it ‚Äújust‚Äù the build system timings?

Volodymyr S (Apple)
2022-06-08 21:19:24

*Thread Reply:* There are no changes in PCH generation/use. Do you have specific improvements in mind? Also you can always provide your suggestions through a feedback report. As for the templates, you are correct, they are not instantiated until they are used. And if they are not used in PCH, it doesn't improve the instantiation time. Have you tried explicit template instantiation in PCH? Does it improve the build time? Build time report doesn't take into account -ftime-report. You can still add the flag yourself and check the generated timing reports.

Mikko
2022-06-08 21:30:04

*Thread Reply:* Haven‚Äôt done too deep exploration on the instantiation issue, analysing build times is a thankless job as it takes a long time to get any results, and separating signal from the noise is hard.

Which reminds me, when using -ftime-report, comparing two results from a bigger build job on a M1 is useless, as sometimes the timing can be from a performance core, and sometimes effeciency. Is there a way to peg a process, like xcodebuild and all its children processes to a certain type of a core?

Volodymyr S (Apple)
2022-06-08 21:33:20

*Thread Reply:* I don't know off top of my head about any mechanism for pegging a process to a certain type of a core. Let me ask around.

üôá Mikko
Volodymyr S (Apple)
2022-06-08 21:37:14

*Thread Reply:* And I totally agree that comparing results for the same file from different cores is frustrating. So close but not actionable.

Volodymyr S (Apple)
2022-06-08 21:53:18

*Thread Reply:* Looks like you can try taskpolicy tool. Specifically force a process into the background to achieve consistent results. Other than that there are no guaranteed ways to force usage of a specific core type.

Mikko
2022-06-08 21:59:13

*Thread Reply:* Ah, sounds a bit slow, but I suppose better than useless timing diffs üôÇ So I guess clamping to background QoS never chooses performance cores then

Mikko
2022-06-08 22:00:14

*Thread Reply:* Thank you! üôÇ

Mikko
2022-06-10 12:45:22

*Thread Reply:* Bah, someone pointed out to me -fpch-instantiate-templates, which would then instantiate the templates in pch, time to experiment!

Swift Forums
Announcing Swift support in CMake
Hello again fellow Swift users, I know that build systems are generally contentious and inspire heated discussions. I do really hope that people will be kind enough to NOT derail this thread into discussions of build systems and the merits and demerits of CMake. There are existing projects which use CMake and this can be valuable for them. I am in no way instructing that this be the way that everyone builds their software. Over the past few years, CMake has really gained a significant amoun...

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 21:21:01

@Maciej asked > What is the state of std::filesystem on Apple platforms? Do you have any recommendations for integrating with system-level file coordination mechanism AND doing so from c++?

Louis D (Apple)
2022-06-08 21:23:12

*Thread Reply:* &lt;filesystem&gt; has been available since macOS 10.15 (and other Apple OSes released in alignment). It is supported out-of-the-box with the C++ Standard Library shipped with Xcode: you should only make sure to compile as C++17 (or above) to get access to the library.

If you are deploying to an earlier target than macOS 10.15 (and aligned OSes), the compiler will complain at compile-time if you try to use something that would not be available on your deployment target.

üëå Maciej
Louis D (Apple)
2022-06-08 21:24:36

*Thread Reply:* Could you clarify what you mean by system-level file coordination mechanisms? I am not sure I understand exactly what is being referred to.

Maciej
2022-06-08 21:48:36

*Thread Reply:* I meant NSFileCoordinator specifically. To illustrate the problem: part of the app might use NSFileCoordinator to move the some file and other one (in c++, possibly much ‚Äúlower level‚Äù) might use &lt;filesystem&gt; to attempt to read it at the same time. Is there any way for this c/c++ part to participate with system file coordination?

Louis D (Apple)
2022-06-08 21:56:25

*Thread Reply:* Unfortunately, the &lt;filesystem&gt; library does not provide any utilities to coordinate reading and writing of files between various "users" of the file, so you'd have to implement that yourself on top of the &lt;filesystem&gt; API.

üëå Maciej
Louis D (Apple)
2022-06-08 21:57:55

*Thread Reply:* The root of the issue here is that the C++ Standard does not have provisions for &lt;filesystem&gt; to track changes to files, it's somewhat lower level than that.

Maciej
2022-06-08 22:01:16

*Thread Reply:* Makes sense! I wonder if there are any other public system headers with C API for achieving such integration without the need to use Foundation, but that‚Äôs another story üôÇ Thanks for the answer @Louis D (Apple)! üôÇ

Kevin P (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:02:53

*Thread Reply:* NSFileCoordinator is a strictly Foundation-level concept, so at this time there isn‚Äôt any lower level API that interacts with the subsystem.

üëå Maciej
Maciej
2022-06-08 22:07:25

*Thread Reply:* Good to know! I always thought NSFileCoordinator in Foundation only provides a wrapper to some file system level functionality. But now I have no idea how NSFileCoordinator achieves coordination across processes üòÑ

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 21:46:35

@Fernando asked > Can the "any" extential types be deployed to earlier OS versions, or does it require the 5.7 runtime? Thanks!

Joe G (Apple)
2022-06-08 21:47:58

*Thread Reply:* any P for any protocol type will work on older runtimes. With associated types it's a bit more complicated. You can't generally use any P&lt;Type&gt; as a first-class type without the 5.7 runtime, but you can use it in stored properties of other types, allowing you to write a wrapper struct that can be back deployed

Joe G (Apple)
2022-06-08 21:49:37

*Thread Reply:* // this will be back deployable struct AnyP&lt;T&gt; { var value: any P&lt;T&gt; }

ü§î Adrian, Fernando, Michal
Adam
2022-06-09 00:03:19

*Thread Reply:* Is there a concrete code example of what cannot be done without 5.7 and how this back deployable struct would work for older deployment targets?

Joe G (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:07:12

*Thread Reply:* You won't be able to expose the property directly as public API, but it will behave as expected in your internal implementation‚Äîas long as you're using a new enough Xcode, you can call methods on it etc. internally. So you can use any P&lt;T&gt; as a way of more easily implementing a type-erasing wrapper that you might've used subclassing or closures for previously.

üëç Adam
John M (Apple)
2022-06-09 04:14:19

*Thread Reply:* Basically, you won‚Äôt be able to use those types as a ‚Äútype argument‚Äù: if you‚Äôre calling a generic function or using a generic type over &lt;T&gt;, you can‚Äôt let T be any Collection&lt;Int&gt; (or any type that uses it as part of its identity, like (any Collection&lt;Int&gt;)? or (Int, Float, any Collection&lt;Int&gt;))

John M (Apple)
2022-06-09 04:17:13

*Thread Reply:* But the types of properties aren‚Äôt part of the identity of a struct or class, and any types have fixed static layouts, so it turns out that you can just wrap them inside other types and the runtime will get by just fine

Adam
2022-06-10 20:47:09

*Thread Reply:* Is the Swift 5.7 runtime iOS (16) bound or is it built in with the app?

Jeremy A (Apple)
2022-06-08 21:47:20

Reminder: We‚Äôre 10 minutes from wrapping up!

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 21:53:34

@Alexander asked > I have two, possibly obscure questions: 1) is the --disassembler-options=no-aliases not supported for objdump? and 2) Is there comprehensive documentation for the as assembler anywhere?

üôè Alexander
Steven W (Apple)
2022-06-08 21:55:38

*Thread Reply:* You can find the documentation for objdump here: https://llvm.org/docs/CommandGuide/llvm-objdump.html --disassembler-options should work like following but it doesn't work for you, please file a feedback report to us: objdump --macho --disassemble-all --disassembler-options=no-aliases arm64.o

üëç Alexander, Andrew
‚úîÔ∏è Alexander
Steven W (Apple)
2022-06-08 21:56:10

*Thread Reply:* For as , it is just an alias to clang. You can just build your assembly file with clang instead.

Alexander
2022-06-08 21:57:58

*Thread Reply:* True. What I was referring to was more the syntax and keywords. Like, gcc as will accept ` ADD X2, X1, X0, SXTB clang needs ADD X2, X1, W0, SXTB

Alexander
2022-06-08 21:58:26

*Thread Reply:* or MUL V6.4H, V0.4H, V3.4H[0] vs MUL.4H V6, V0, V3[0]

Steven W (Apple)
2022-06-08 21:58:33

*Thread Reply:* as exists as an compatibility tool to binutils. You can find documentation by running man as on commandline

Alexander
2022-06-08 22:00:33

*Thread Reply:* As to objdump, thank you, I was doing it wrong!

Amara E (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:01:55

*Thread Reply:* To me, that looks like GCC is incorrect in accepting ADD X2, X1, X0, SXTB

Alexander
2022-06-08 22:03:40

*Thread Reply:* @Amara E (Apple) That may very well be the case! I would still be very happy to find the authoretive guide to the correct syntax and keywords. So far, I have figured that out on my own üòâ

Amara E (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:04:30

*Thread Reply:* You can find the official assembler spec in the ARM architecture reference manual, for aarch64 in particular.

Amara E (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:05:24

*Thread Reply:* You can also see some assembler documentation from ARM's assembler docs: https://developer.arm.com/documentation/dui0801/g/A64-General-Instructions/ADD--extended-register- the table at the bottom I believe shows that the extended reg should be Wn

‚úîÔ∏è Alexander
Alexander
2022-06-08 22:05:39

*Thread Reply:* @Amara E (Apple) And, I‚Äôm not saying you‚Äôd be wrong with that, any deviation that is in gcc is likely wrong?

Amara E (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:07:38

*Thread Reply:* Perhaps incorrect/wrong is too strong of a term, especially for a project like GCC which we aren't associated with. They may well choose to do this on purpose as a convenience for developers.

‚úîÔ∏è Alexander
Alexander
2022-06-08 22:07:57

*Thread Reply:* For MUL though I find: MUL Vd.T, Vn.T, Vm.Ts[index] whereas clang wants: MUL.4H V6, V0, V3[0]

Alexander
2022-06-08 22:09:31

*Thread Reply:* Here, the docs look exactly like what gcc is accepting: MUL V6.4H, V0.4H, V3.4H[0]

Amara E (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:15:42

*Thread Reply:* This is likely due to the assembler expecting Apple's NEON assembler syntax (due to historical...reasons).

‚úîÔ∏è Alexander
Amara E (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:15:59

*Thread Reply:* I'll check if there's a way to change that...

üòä Alexander
Amara E (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:25:27

*Thread Reply:* Oh it looks like it's not related to the Apple neon syntax actually. If you remove the 4 in v3.4h[0] it works

:gratitude_thank_you: Alexander
Amara E (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:26:02

*Thread Reply:* https://developer.arm.com/documentation/dui0801/g/A64-SIMD-Vector-Instructions/MUL--vector--by-element-

:gratitude_danke: Alexander
Amara E (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:26:57

*Thread Reply:* That page says that the final type specifier is either H or S, not sure why GCC accepts 4H. Maybe it's a bug, maybe it's a feature. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Amara E (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:27:37

*Thread Reply:* But it also seems that as should accept the official ARM assembler syntax too, no need to do anything special.

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:25:20

@Paul asked > Our system has a well defined data model with data structures and algorithms that are intuitive to understand and reason about for our business logic. I'm a bit dismayed at the prospect of being forced to carve these structures into other units (actors) to satisfy language requirements while undertaking the migration of our algorithms and processes to utilize Swift concurrency. This seems to impact readability, concise modeling, and ultimately maintainability. I'd like to maintain an open mind about this, though, since I've used async/await syntax so effectively in single-threaded languages. > And so I'm wondering if you have any best practices or guidelines to share in adding this new dimension to our data modeling. Should actors be long-lived objects? Are monolithic singletons as actors discouraged or should we model after MainActor? Should we be as > granular as possible?

Konrad M (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:25:45

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for asking Paul, I'm sure this is on the mind of many devs as the new isolation features add a new "axis" to your design process.

The goal of Swift concurrency is to give you the tools to control how your data is accessed from different concurrent contexts. You‚Äôve probably already made your code safe against concurrency, and you shouldn‚Äôt need to completely rewrite that around actors. Instead, you just need to tell Swift how you‚Äôre making things safe, and then the compiler will help enforce that you‚Äôre getting it right.

As a guide for granularity: you can carve out things which should be executed concurrently into independent actors; Things which definitely should NOT be executed concurrently, should live on the same actor. This way you'll navigate your way to the amount of actors that make sense for your use-case.

The Eliminate data races using Swift Concurrency session from today is a good resource to get into this mindset.

Apple Developer
Eliminate data races using Swift Concurrency - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
Join us as we explore one of the core concepts in Swift concurrency: isolation of tasks and actors. We'll take you through Swift's...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/110351/
üôá Artyom
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:27:57

@Adrien asked > Hello, > You wrote that AsyncChannel and AsyncThrowingChannel was heavily inspired from [Combine] Subject > But is it possible to have multiple subscription to a single AsyncChannel ? It seems not. Why not?

üëç Robert
Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:28:10

*Thread Reply:* so i kinda touched on this a bit before

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:28:24

*Thread Reply:* https://wwdc22.slack.com/archives/C03H0JN431U/p1654636897761789?thread_ts=1654636838.973459&cid=C03H0JN431U

} Philippe H (Apple) (https://wwdc22.slack.com/team/U03H36UD5QX)
<p>That got changed in swift 5.7: originally the problem was that the case that multiple consumers was undefined behavior, but we refined that to now allow for multiple consumers. But note: each consumer will consume the iteration independently so they will not share the values.</p>
Original URL: https://wwdc22.slack.com/archives/C03H0JN431U/p1654636897761789?thread_ts=1654636838.973459&amp;cid=C03H0JN431U
From a thread in <b>#devtools-and-swift-lounge</b>
Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:28:53

*Thread Reply:* so they will support multiple consuming, but those consumers wont share the values as they are sent

Adrien
2022-06-08 22:31:36

*Thread Reply:* Sorry I didn't see this previous answer üôè But the question is still (somewhat üôÇ ) relevant : if the consumers don't receive the same values the behavior is different from Subject. Can you explain the advantage of this choice?

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:32:44

*Thread Reply:* part of that is that the iteration is stateful; having them share the values would put a big burden on folks writing their own AsyncSequences - it would end up getting into some gnarly bits like using locks etc

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:33:11

*Thread Reply:* now there is evolution of the swift-async-algorithms package and that is an ongoing discussion of what the solution for that will be

üëç Robert
Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:33:25

*Thread Reply:* because sharing is something folks want and need (rightfully so)

üôè Adrien
Shilpa C (Apple)

Myke S (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:47:19

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:33:52

@Alexey asked > Is there any way to guarantee that a Task will run not on the main thread?

Rokhini P (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:34:12

*Thread Reply: A task only runs on the main thread under the following circumstances: * When it is running a main actor isolated function ** If the task has been created from the context of a main actor isolated function, then it will inherit the main actor and run on the main thread

If your task has none of these properties, it should not run on the main thread.

Alexey
2022-06-08 22:35:38

*Thread Reply:* Thank you!

Adam
2022-06-08 22:35:56

*Thread Reply:* Since a view controller is typically main actor isolated, you would need to use Task.detached(), right?

üëÄ Alexey
John M (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:36:03

*Thread Reply:* Tasks are designed to move fluidly between actors, running wherever the code needs it to run

John M (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:36:36

*Thread Reply:* Sync functions that aren‚Äôt actor-isolated will run wherever their caller was running

John M (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:37:33

*Thread Reply:* Async functions, however, will actively switch off actors if they aren‚Äôt actor-isolated, so you can always tell where they‚Äôre running statically

John M (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:38:20

*Thread Reply:* So if you call an async function that isn‚Äôt part of an actor and doesn‚Äôt inherit actor isolation from its context, it will not run on an actor

John M (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:39:58

*Thread Reply:* If you‚Äôre in a view controller, yeah, that‚Äôs likely main actor isolated, so Task { /****this code****/ } will also be isolated. But if that code calls something async that‚Äôs not isolated, then you can be confident that that code won‚Äôt be running on the main actor, and you don‚Äôt specifically need to detach to do that

Doug G (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:41:55

*Thread Reply:* If you haven't seen it yet, we cover this in more detail in the session "Eliminate data races with Swift Concurrency": https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/110351/

Alexey
2022-06-08 22:44:09

*Thread Reply:* If I use let v = await doSomething() it execute in main thread. But if I use async let v = doSomething() it execute in secondary thread. And yes, I am in a view controller. Is it a normal behavior or I do something wrong?

Doug G (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:46:48

*Thread Reply:* That is the intended behavior. The initializer for async let runs in a child task that is concurrent with the code that declared v

Jonathan G (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:47:32

*Thread Reply:* If doSomething() is main-actor-isolated and the current function is also, what's the effect?

Doug G (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:48:50

*Thread Reply:* The child task will start and then immediately suspect until the main actor is available.

Jonathan G (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:50:02

*Thread Reply:* And if the caller awaits the value v, it should suspend the caller and start executing doSomething()?

Doug G (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:54:19

*Thread Reply:* Yes, the caller has to await to get the value of v, at which point the child task can execute doSomething().

Jonathan G (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:55:38

*Thread Reply:* Cool, thanks!

Alexey
2022-06-08 22:57:35

*Thread Reply:* Thank you!

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:34:59

@Paul asked > Are Actors intended to be long lived objects? Do they have a lifecycle?

Kavon F (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:35:59

*Thread Reply:* You can define and use the actor type like other types in the language. An actor instance is inexpensive to create and use for coordination in a concurrent program. You can define an init and deinit for an actor's lifecycle management.

üëç Paul, Konrad M (Apple), Adam
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:37:21

@David asked > Given all of the recent changes and additions to swift concurrency through async/await, async sequence and now async algorithms, and given that combine has not changed in obvious ways, should those of us that have leveraged combine as the basis of our concurrency models within our apps be looking at migrating these towards the async await styles or are these likely to remain true siblings within Swift ecosystem?

üëç Eduardo
Konrad M (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:37:43

*Thread Reply:* In general both systems have a place of their own; The new async APIs, thanks to their help from the compiler, are able to provide better ergonomics and safety, so they've got some clear advantages here. This does not mean that there is no place for Combine though -- Tony had a great thread explaining the team's thoughts on this yesterday, see here: https://wwdc22.slack.com/archives/C03H0JN431U/p1654628520096709?thread_ts=1654628350.752979&cid=C03H0JN431U

} Tony P (Apple) (https://wwdc22.slack.com/team/U03HL5K6L04)
<p>Great question, thanks @Stefan. You‚Äôre 100% correct that there are a lot of ways to add concurrency to your project. It‚Äôs been a long-standing challenge to make concurrency safe and easy to understand. I hope you‚Äôll forgive my bias, but given the channel we‚Äôre in I‚Äôll say this ‚Äî async/await is the best way to use concurrency in your app. If you can use it, use that first. You‚Äôve probably seen that we‚Äôre actively improving it over time as well, with more support for <code>Sendable</code> this year, additional algorithms for Async Sequence, and more.</p>
Original URL: https://wwdc22.slack.com/archives/C03H0JN431U/p1654628520096709?thread_ts=1654628350.752979&amp;cid=C03H0JN431U
From a thread in <b>#devtools-and-swift-lounge</b>

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:39:14

@Shinzan asked > About Minimal Strict Concurrency Checking, do we need to add Sendable conformance to struct and enum even though they are implicitly Sendable if we want to check Sendability?

Doug G (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:39:43

*Thread Reply:* The compiler will infer the Sendableconformance for these types unless there is an explicitly-non-Sendable type in their instance data. If you want to be sure that the types are Sendable, add the explicit conformance and the compiler will produce warnings for types used in instance data that aren't known to be Sendable.

üëç Shinzan
Shinzan
2022-06-08 22:41:54

*Thread Reply:* Thank you!

Shinzan
2022-06-08 23:13:16

*Thread Reply:* Sorry, I have one more question. If structs and enums are implicitly Sendable, does Xcode emit warning to this redundant explicit conformance when we change Checking mode?

Doug G (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:18:08

*Thread Reply:* No, it will not. If you place an explicit Sendable conformance on your struct or enum, that will suppress the implicit Sendable conformance

üëç Shinzan
Shinzan
2022-06-08 23:23:11

*Thread Reply:* I see. Thank you very much!

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:45:28

@Adrian asked > In Xcode 14, some of the UIKit structs like UIEdgeInsets have their Sendable conformances marked explicitly as unavailable. That's a bit surprising, given that they are trivial data types. Why is that, and what's the purpose of conforming to Sendable and marking this as unavailable?

Becca R (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:45:55

*Thread Reply:* It looks like an accident that UIEdgeInsets was marked explicitly non-Sendable in the header. Please file a report in Feedback Assistant and we‚Äôll look into it!

üëç Adrian
Adrian
2022-06-08 22:47:35

*Thread Reply:* Thanks! So writing @available(**, unavailable) extension X: Sendable means that a type is explicitly not thread safe?

Becca R (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:55:36

*Thread Reply:* Yes, exactly. The compiler treats an explicitly unavailable Sendable conformance as a stronger sign that the type is not thread-safe, so it may treat them slightly differently from ones that are simply missing‚Äîfor instance, it may show warnings it would normally suppress, or phrase them differently, or suggest different Fix-Its.

üôá Adrian
Adrian
2022-06-08 23:00:59

*Thread Reply:* Got it, thanks!

Adrian
2022-06-08 23:01:03

*Thread Reply:* The feedback number is FB10112675.

üôá‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Becca R (Apple)

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:48:15

@Duncan asked > In trying to test code that used an AsyncSequence recently, I discovered that for NotificationCenter.Notifications the underlying subscription isn't established before the sequence value is returned to the caller, which results in test failures due to race conditions. > > My expectation would be that a sequence value should not be returned for an AsyncSequence until it is ready to respond to the events in question‚Äîbut the AsyncSequence protocol does not specific this per se. Do you think that is a reasonable expectation?

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:48:23

*Thread Reply:* I think this might be a bug; could you please file a feedback on that? The notifications sequence does register for the notifications and under normal scenarios does ensure they are pending before returning to the client.

Duncan
2022-06-08 22:48:59

*Thread Reply:* I definitely am planning on filing a Feedback, with a sample project. I was waiting to test this on iOS 16/Xcode 14 in case the behavior changed first.

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:49:04

*Thread Reply:* There is obviously a small window between the call and the actual registration that things might slip into in obscure cases

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:49:27

*Thread Reply:* worth filing a bug either way üòâ

üëç:skin_tone_3: Duncan
Duncan
2022-06-08 22:49:28

*Thread Reply:* It led to quite some discussion (arguments?) here: https://forums.swift.org/t/reliably-testing-code-that-adopts-swift-concurrency/57304/71

Swift Forums
Reliably testing code that adopts Swift Concurrency?
I think this is absolutely key. I suggest what the example and investigations here in the thread have established is that there is a clear flaw in the implementation of AsyncSequence. It is a reasonable expectation of this type that when you await its initialization, it does not return until it is listening to the events it will handle. What is required is a bug report/evolution proposal to request that AsyncSequence behaves as would be expected in an async-await world. With that, no additiona...
Original URL: https://forums.swift.org/t/reliably-testing-code-that-adopts-swift-concurrency/57304/71
Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:49:45

*Thread Reply:* yea ive been following that - quite an interesting topic in general

Duncan
2022-06-08 22:50:15

*Thread Reply:* ‚Ä¶ where my view was async/await code is generally fairly easily testable, but the OP and others appeared to be of the belief that the majority of it is not.

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:51:03

*Thread Reply:* i am pretty sure asynchronous code is testable, but sometimes things can get a bit tricky so i can see where it could be daunting

Duncan
2022-06-08 23:35:36

*Thread Reply:* Well dang, it looks like the conclusion in that thread and my pointing at NotificationCentre.Notifications was wrong. Having extracted the test into one that removes the View and ViewModel initialization of the original example, this test passes 100,000 times without error:

Duncan
2022-06-08 23:35:47

*Thread Reply:* **import** XCTest

**class** AsyncSequenceTests: XCTestCase {

**func** test_notificationCentreNotifications_doesNotDisplayInitializationRaceCondition_whenRun100000times() **async** **throws** { // Actions and expectation **let** expectation = **self**.expectation(description: "Notification received.") **let** fulfillExpectation = { expectation.fulfill() }

// Initiate the NotificationCentre.Notifications AsyncSequence
`**let** asyncSequenceTask = Task {`
  `**let** screenshotSequence = **await** NotificationCenter.default.notifications(`
    named: UIApplication.userDidTakeScreenshotNotification
  )
  **`for`** `**await** _ **in** screenshotSequence {`
    fulfillExpectation()
  }
}

// Post the notification created when a screenshot occurs.
_ = `**await** MainActor.run {`
  Task.detached(priority:.userInitiated, operation: {
    `**await** <a href="http://NotificationCenter.default.post">NotificationCenter.default.post</a>(name: UIApplication.userDidTakeScreenshotNotification, object: **nil**)`
  })
}

// Test expectations
**`await`** `**self**.waitForExpectations(timeout: 10)`
asyncSequenceTask.cancel()

}

}

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:54:48

*Thread Reply:* that is a bit much to really get into on slack - id have to really pull it apart; make sure to file a feedback with any repro case like that

üëç:skin_tone_3: Duncan
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:56:52

@Francis asked > Hi! Thank you for taking the time to answer our questions. I was wondering what is a recommended approach for serializing a series of async functions with Swift concurrency, so that they run one at a time, and run in order so one must complete before the next? My current attempt involves an AsyncStream within an actor, but it seems complex and I'm unsure it is correct: > > &gt; final class Repository { &gt; func _request(_ requestMethod: RequestMethod) async throws -&gt; RequestResult { &gt; // Execute an async request against a remote or local source (perhaps both)... &gt; } &gt; } &gt; &gt; actor AsyncUserRepositoryWithStream { &gt; private let repository: AsyncUserRepository &gt; &gt; struct StreamElement { &gt; let continuation: CheckedContinuation&lt;AsyncUserRepository.RequestResult, Error&gt; &gt; let action: () async throws -&gt; AsyncUserRepository.RequestResult &gt; } &gt; &gt; var task: Task&lt;Void, Error&gt;! &gt; var stream: AsyncStream&lt;StreamElement&gt;! &gt; var streamContinuation: AsyncStream&lt;StreamElement&gt;.Continuation! &gt; &gt; init(urlSession: URLSession, baseUrl: URL, persistentContainer: NSPersistentContainer) { &gt; self.repository = .init(urlSession: urlSession, baseUrl: baseUrl, persistentContainer: persistentContainer) &gt; &gt; var streamContinuation: AsyncStream&lt;StreamElement&gt;.Continuation! &gt; &gt; stream = AsyncStream { &gt; streamContinuation = $0 &gt; } &gt; &gt; self.streamContinuation = streamContinuation &gt; } &gt; &gt; func request(_ requestMethod: RequestMethod) async throws -&gt; AsyncUserRepository.RequestResult { &gt; if task == nil { &gt; task = Task { &gt; for await element in stream { &gt; do { &gt; let result = try await element.action() &gt; element.continuation.resume(returning: result) &gt; } catch { &gt; element.continuation.resume(throwing: error) &gt; } &gt; } &gt; } &gt; } &gt; &gt; let result = try await withCheckedThrowingContinuation { (continuation: CheckedContinuation&lt;AsyncUserRepository.RequestResult, Error&gt;) in &gt; streamContinuation.yield( &gt; .init( &gt; continuation: continuation, &gt; action: { &gt; try await self.repository._request(requestMethod) &gt; } &gt; ) &gt; ) &gt; } &gt; &gt; return result &gt; } &gt; } &gt; > > Do you have a recommended approach?

Rokhini P (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:57:22

*Thread Reply:* Please do file a Feedback request with some information about your motivating use case for requiring FIFO behaviour. In the meantime, a potential approach to get the desired behaviour with existing constructs, would be to make Repository an actor which has a queue of work items. It then creates a single Task in its initializer to drain that queue of work items - thereby giving you FIFO ordering as well as mutual exclusion.

:gratitude_thank_you: Francis, Quindarius
John M (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:36:33

*Thread Reply:* You might also consider just using a non-actor class that protects the queue with its own internal lock; that way, you‚Äôll be able to enqueue things on it synchronously

Francis
2022-06-08 23:45:58

*Thread Reply:* Thank you both! This is indeed something where I have to rethink things. The basic use case is serializing access (reads/writes) to a remote server resource that is also backed by Core Data. There can be a number of inflight requests that I want to make sure are in order, e.g. fetch a user resource from a server, store in Core Data, then later write an update to the user resource to Core Data, and then write that update to the server. These can be repeated many times, alongside fetches

I have previously approached this with a DispatchSemaphore(value: 1)

John M (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:48:28

*Thread Reply:* It‚Äôs definitely something we‚Äôre thinking about. Understanding what the code looks like that wants to use this would be helpful ‚Äî in particular, whether it‚Äôs likely to want to wait, whether you rely on FIFO ordering or just want to make sure that events don‚Äôt interleave, etc.

Francis
2022-06-08 23:52:59

*Thread Reply:* Thanks, I have a larger code sample with unit tests I‚Äôll be sure to submit!

üëç John M (Apple)
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:57:38

@Heiko asked > How can the Reader/Writer problem solved efficiently with Swift concurrency? Write operations should have exclusive access (serialized), readers can perform in parallel. Actors serialize everything, which is not optimal from a performance perspective.

Rokhini P (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:58:11

*Thread Reply:* In general, we have found that reader writer locks sound like a good idea in theory, but in practice they degrade to bad behaviour including lack of priority inversion avoidance support, starvation issues etc. Most use cases we have found are able to perform just as well while using an efficient lock implementation - like OSAllocatedUnfairLock or actors. If you have a motivating use case that needs RW locks, we‚Äôd like to hear about it, so please do file a Feedback request.

Jonathan G (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:03:17

*Thread Reply:* For more information on OSAllocatedUnfairLock, which is new in macOS Ventura and iOS 16, see https://developer.apple.com/documentation/os/osallocatedunfairlock

John M (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:16:29

*Thread Reply:* I would add that if something is both heavily contended and heavily biased towards readers, the best solution is usually to jump all the way to a lockless algorithm like read-copy-update

John M (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:20:51

*Thread Reply:* Even in the short term, if you can‚Äôt make make the leap to be truly lockless, holding a lock briefly while you copy or overwrite the value should have similar overhead to a reader/writer lock, and you‚Äôll be forced to architect clients in a way that‚Äôs consistent with a lockless approach if you eventually adopt one

John M (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:25:32

*Thread Reply:* Or you can simply use a lock normally but design your data so that reads spend very little time in the critical section, e.g. just copying a small COW data structure or object reference

John M (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:30:02

*Thread Reply:* The key insight here is that acquiring a reader/writer lock is usually not cheaper than acquiring a mutex, so the only efficiency win is parallelism within reads, which you can mostly duplicate by simply reducing the amount of time you spend in the critical section during those reads

Joe G (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:36:06

*Thread Reply:* if you want to integrate data structures with manual synchronization into an actor, such as lockless data structures or data structures with manually-tuned locking like what @John M (Apple) described, you could define them in a Sendable class and expose them in actors as nonisolated properties, which will allow code to access them from the actor without going through the actor's own queue

Joe G (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:44:36

*Thread Reply:* (or even traditional pthread_rwlocks, if you've established your existing code benefits from using them)

Heiko
2022-06-09 08:21:19

*Thread Reply:* Thanks a lot for taking the time to answer my question and all the suggestions! I will look into custom locking behavior within an actor.

The way we currently solve it is to setup NSOperation dependencies when an operation is enqueued (within specific groups of operations that relate to a certain part of the model). This guarantees that operations are executed in the desired order. That's a very easy to understand solution to the problem and not as error-prone as locking because the details are abstracted away behind the dependency management of the queue.

It would be really great to have more control over the execution order of tasks in certain cases without having to fallback to locking via mutexes etc.

Joe G (Apple)
2022-06-10 18:07:56

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the reply! It would be great to get a feedback report from you about what you're trying to accomplish, if you have a moment to write up more. We're looking into adding more facilities to control execution order and having examples of what people are doing in practice will help inform our design. In the meantime, it may help to think about managing execution order within a single task, rather than trying to coordinate execution order across different tasks‚Äîfor instance, you could have an actor that holds onto a queue of work items that other tasks can send work items to, and a single task that drains the queue in order.

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:58:52

@Derik asked > If Task { is called from a MainActor, does that mean the Task will always run on the main thread?

John M (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:00:33

*Thread Reply:* It‚Äôll start running on the main thread, but tasks flow between actors as needed. In particular, if the task calls an async function which isn‚Äôt actor-isolated, it‚Äôll switch off of the main actor while it‚Äôs in that function, and it‚Äôll only switch back when it calls or returns to code that‚Äôs actor-isolated again

John M (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:02:07

*Thread Reply:* There‚Äôs more about this in today‚Äôs session called ‚ÄúEliminate data races with Swift Concurrency‚Äù: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/110351/

üëç Derik, Michael
Derik
2022-06-08 23:02:43

*Thread Reply:* So an async function inside a MainActor makes an await call. That await will switch off of the main actor?

John M (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:23:23

*Thread Reply:* If it‚Äôs calling an async function that isn‚Äôt MainActor-isolated, yes

üëç Derik
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:02:09

@Raimundas asked > I have a question about structured concurrency cancelation. In particular best practice for sharing responsibilities when canceling. > > Given the code snipet: > &gt; ... &gt; task = Task { &gt; let longRunningWorker = LongRunningWorker(inputURL: fileURL) &gt; fileURL = try await longRunningWorker!.doAsyncWork() &gt; &gt; let image = try await ImageService.i.generateImage() &gt; let modifiedImage = try await doSomeMoreAsyncWork(image) &gt; let andMore = try await andSomeMore(modifiedImage) &gt; } &gt; ... &gt; > > At some point I might call task.cancel(). How that should be handled? > > After reading all of the tutorials I see two paths and I'm not sure which one is better: > 1) Add try Task.checkCancellation() after each line in the code snippet above > 2) Those async methods should handle cancellation in-them which would result in some boilerplate code in each of them.

Konrad M (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:02:24

*Thread Reply:* You're right to observe that task cancellation is cooperative in Swift; So you'll need to write the checking "somewhere" to interrupt the work.

The question is equally about semantics and code organization at that point -- do you control those other APIs? Do they perhaps already throw on cancellation? If they can't be made to respect it, you can add the checks yourself after/before calls to them.

In general it depends on the frameworks you're using and if they handle it or you have to yourself -- refer to their documentation to find out.

Konrad M (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:03:24

*Thread Reply:* It also might not be worth checking before "every" operation; You should check before starting some "heavy" work, or in order to avoid holding onto precious resources for longer than necessary etc. On the other hand, it's some cheap call, letting it run might be just fine.

üôè Raimundas
üëç Raimundas
Raimundas
2022-06-08 23:03:57

*Thread Reply:* Thank you for your answers. Assuming all those APIs are in-house, the approach where those methods handle their cancellation is preferred, correct?

Konrad M (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:04:26

*Thread Reply:* most likely, but keep in mind what semantics you want from it all üôÇ

Raimundas
2022-06-08 23:05:47

*Thread Reply:* Thank you

üôå Konrad M (Apple)
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:03:05

@Oleksii asked > If MainActor func is called from MainActor context is there a way to execute it synchronously without scheduling for the next loop?

David S (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:03:29

*Thread Reply:* nice question

Evan W (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:03:34

*Thread Reply:* If we know that we are on the main actor, the call is made synchronously.

John M (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:05:26

*Thread Reply:* That‚Äôs generally true for calls between actors. If they‚Äôre dynamically between the same actor, there‚Äôs no scheduling overhead

Oleksii
2022-06-08 23:05:28

*Thread Reply:* but, if the func is called inside of the main thread, but not in MainActor context, then it‚Äôs not called immediately?

John M (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:05:57

*Thread Reply:* By ‚Äúcall‚Äù, do you mean something like Task { call(); }?

Oleksii
2022-06-08 23:06:26

*Thread Reply:* yes

John M (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:07:47

*Thread Reply:* Okay. The code inside Task {} does not run synchronously, and no, there‚Äôs currently no way to run part of it synchronously. If you need something to happen synchronously, you need to pull it out of the Task {}

Oleksii
2022-06-08 23:08:19

*Thread Reply:* okay. Thank you for the answer

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:03:17

@Oron asked > Hi, with the new Async Algorithms for AsyncSequence, how would you use .debounce for example, on a SwiftUI TextField text change? (i.e how would you convert a text change to a an AsyncSequence) I know how to do it with Combine (or RxSwift) but can't grab my head around how to do this with AsyncSequence

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:03:25

*Thread Reply:* So the way to get the values is to emit them into something like an AsyncStream ; when a value needs to be emitted it can be sent via the AsyncStream&lt;String&gt;.Continuation's yield method.

Oron
2022-06-08 23:07:19

*Thread Reply:* Thanks, I‚Äôll try that! I don‚Äôt think that there are any examples of it yet, so if you have a link to a usage example of it, it would be lovely! Thanks again!

Aura Lily V (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:12:55

*Thread Reply:* there‚Äôs a short example of AsyncStream use in its documentation: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swift/asyncstream

Aura Lily V (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:13:14

*Thread Reply:* you would capture the continuation and call its yield method when the text changes.

Oron
2022-06-08 23:14:40

*Thread Reply:* Got it, so I guess the continuation needs to be captured outside of the SwiftUI View otherwise it‚Äôll reset it upon state change, right?

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:16:47

*Thread Reply:* yea, that is a supported (and relatively common) way of using it

Oron
2022-06-08 23:17:52

*Thread Reply:* Something like that?: TextField("Your Location", text: $location) .onChange(of: location) { viewModel.capturedTextfieldCntinuation.yield($0) } ```class ViewModel { var capturedTextfieldCntinuation: ...

var textFieldStream: { AsyncStream { continuation in capturedTextfieldCntinuation = continuation } }

textFieldStream .debounce() ... }```

Oron
2022-06-08 23:20:43

*Thread Reply:* Or is there maybe another way to turn a @Published which is bound to the textfield to an AsyncStream?

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:21:22

*Thread Reply:* .values is a property on all Publisher types that is an AsyncSequence

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:22:37

*Thread Reply:* so yea, that would work too

Oron
2022-06-08 23:24:32

Philippe H (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:25:36

*Thread Reply:* @Published remains a good way to interact with SwiftUI

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:07:41

@Edward asked > Do you have any recommendations for debugging race conditions when the repo uses a mix of completion handlers, combine pipelines, and async?

Daniel D (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:08:21

*Thread Reply:* For debugging data races and other memory safety issues in an App, sanitizers are a good general purpose tool and a great starting place (TSAN, ASAN, UBSan). If you're interested in specifically analyzing Swift Tasks/Actors, the new Swift Concurrency Template in Instruments 14 (Visualize and optimize Swift Concurrency) can provide a lot of additional insight and may help debugging these types of race conditions.

‚úÖ Edward
üëç Michael
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:26:42

@Lukas asked > How do we opt out of clang-tidy checks in the analyzer? (i.e. bugprone-move-forwarding-reference)

Lukas
2022-06-08 23:29:17

*Thread Reply:* Apologies, didn't realize the previous Q&A was over :)

Shilpa C (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:34:50

*Thread Reply:* Hey Lukas. Unfortunately, we don't have the right people here right to answer this questions. You can make a 1:1 appointment for the C, C++, Objective-C compiler, analyzer, sanitizer, debugger, and linker lab on Friday to get your answer.

From https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/topics/developer-tools/#current: > C, C++, Objective-C compiler, analyzer, sanitizer, debugger, and linker lab > Friday @ 1:00 - 4:00 p.m.

Artem D (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:36:07

*Thread Reply:* Hi, I just found your question! There are build settings to control individual static analysis checks. They live in Project build settings in "Static Analysis - Issues - ..." sections. In particular, bugprone-move-forwarding-reference is controlled by the setting "Moves of Universal References" in section "Static Analysis - Issues - C++" (the setting name in the config files is CLANG_TIDY_BUGPRONE_MOVE_FORWARDING_REFERENCE). We're also curious whether you've encountered any specific problems with the check! We can further discuss them here or in the Webex lab linked above or you can always tell us about them through Feedback Assistant.

Lukas
2022-06-09 19:00:34

*Thread Reply:* Thank you @Artem D (Apple) for getting back to me on this! There are no real problems with the check, we just have a large codebase and want to light up static analysis overall but don't want to wait for every check to be green. We want to do it incrementally.

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:27:02

@David asked > I am using NSProgress to handle task cancellation because it is used by some low level code. Is it sendable? What do I need to do to use NSProgress with tasks and Swift concurrency?

Konrad M (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:27:26

*Thread Reply:* So while NSProgress is Sendable, you have to be careful with how you use it.

The "implicit" APIs it has ( "Adding a Progress Operation Implicitly https://developer.apple.com/documentation/foundation/nsprogress ) relies on thread local data, so you can't use them safely with async/await.

You could either pass the progress object around explicitly, and update it that way, or manually make sure to use a concrete thread or queue as you use it.

David
2022-06-08 23:32:09

*Thread Reply:* Ok, thanks. I think that explains some issues I was having. Providing my own sync lock around its access. I am trying to coordinate Asynchronous Fetch for searching a large dataset with the UI search field. I need to add more projections.

David
2022-06-08 23:32:44

*Thread Reply: Protections*

Konrad M (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:33:19

*Thread Reply:* maybe you can ensure all the places you update the progress from are on main actor or something similar?

Konrad M (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:33:54

*Thread Reply:* actually sorry that still would not be safe; if you'd have more progress objects; and suspensions happen between; you could end up with the wrong on in a thread local

Konrad M (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:34:10

*Thread Reply:* long story short: thread local based apis won't work in combination with async/await

David
2022-06-08 23:36:23

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, it took a lot to get it "reliable‚Äù in the current release which immediately broke in iOS 16.

2022-06-08 23:59:44
