DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 23:44:37

@Adrian asked > I'm seeing a concurrency warning in my UIViewController.deinit in which I'm calling NotificationCenter.default.removeObserver(observer). This is the documented & recommended technique in UIKit. The warning says: "cannot access property 'observer' with a non-sendable type '(any NSObjectProtocol')?." How I can keep using this old-school UIKit pattern while also satisfying strict concurrency checks? I've seen some recent discussions around concurrency + (de)initializers but I don't fully understand them.

Daniel D (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:44:58

*Thread Reply:* Waiting until deinit to removeObserver() is a bit late. Even if a view controller object is primarily used on the main thread, the deinit can occur on a background thread if it's ever referenced by code such as a dispatch_async or Swift concurrency.

This is what the compiler's complaining about ‚Äî observer is @MainActor-isolated and deinit can happen anywhere. Please file a feedback report for updating documentation/recommendations to better cover this case, but in the mean time it's probably worthwhile moving the removeObserver() call earlier in the view controller's lifecycle (e.g. viewDidDisappear or another time before the deinit when it makes sense to remove the observation)

üôå Adrian
Adrian
2022-06-08 23:49:07

*Thread Reply:* Thank you for the detailed explanation, Daniel! I understand it now.

Adrian
2022-06-08 23:49:08

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôll make sure to file a radar about updating documentation.

üôè Joe G (Apple)
Adrian
2022-06-08 23:59:33

*Thread Reply:* Opened FB10114021!

Ortwin
2022-06-09 01:23:17

*Thread Reply:* I thought that NotificationCenter observers are automatically removed when the observer is deallocated?

Adrian
2022-06-09 01:51:47

*Thread Reply:* Only targer/selector ones.

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 00:12:53

@Enrico asked > I‚Äôve always wondered what is the use case for the option to change Xcode Project format version. It doesn‚Äôt seem to change anything in my project file. What it is useful for?

Boris B (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:13:09

*Thread Reply:* Certain features require newer versions of the project format, typically Xcode will automatically upgrade you to the appropriate format version. There isn‚Äôt really a reason to select a newer version than what was automatically chosen, but it can be useful to pick an older one if you need your project to be compatible with older tools.

Matt
2022-06-09 00:13:49

*Thread Reply:* Would be nice to have a project format that is more friendly to branch merges

üò¨ Enrico, Michal
üòÖ Michal
Michal
2022-06-09 00:16:47

*Thread Reply:* For that case, I'd really recommend exporting as many files & modules as possible to Swift packages. üëå We currently only have AppDelegate.swift directly in the project. üòé

Michal
2022-06-09 00:17:37

*Thread Reply:* None

Screenshot 2022-06-09 at 00.17.31.png
Matt
2022-06-09 00:17:53

*Thread Reply:* Wish I could, but I‚Äôve forked a LARGE open source project and often need to modify the main project for my own tweak.

Enrico
2022-06-09 00:23:19

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for your advice @Michal but.. Isn't that a little too‚Ä¶ ‚Äúextreme‚Äù? Is there any doc/post/tutorial on how/why such approach is beneficial to such extent?

Oron
2022-06-09 00:25:41

*Thread Reply:* @Enrico check pointfreeco isowords tour, they explain this ‚Äúextreme‚Äù approach thoroughly and its benefits

üëç Denis
Michal
2022-06-09 00:27:47

*Thread Reply:* It's always open to discussion ü§î but shortly from our perspective: 1Ô∏è‚É£ it got us rid of most of project file issues, 2Ô∏è‚É£ it helped us greatly with modularisation & domains separation (which we'll definitely find even more useful when thinking about different platforms) and 3Ô∏è‚É£ in ideal case, if everything links nicely statically (all package deps resolve as static), it will be all linked into a single binary, reducing any possible dylib/dynamic frameworks count cons (which are probably already a thing of a past).

I remember some articles about Airbnb or Uber having hundreds of modules üòÖ that was a bit too much, but we're around 30 and it really helped us significantly.

üëç Enrico, Michael, Gareth, Denis, Steffen

@Andrew asked > I would like the ability to import a swift playground app (.swiftpm) into Xcode and provide the functionality to have Xcode convert it to an Xcode project. Chris M (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:19:54

*Thread Reply:* There isn't currently a way to convert a swiftpm app project to an Xcode project. Thanks for filing the request.

Can you share why you'd like to convert from one project type to another? Perhaps there are other ways to help solve what you need. For example, you could put shared code in a package and both your swiftpm app project and Xcode project could import the package as a dependency.

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 00:22:38

@Matt asked > Might be more of a SPM question, but with Xcode 14 I see about 30 times every time that "Resolve Packages" runs: > > > Showing Recent Messages > Usage of /Users/me/Library/org.swift.swiftpm/collections.json has been deprecated. Please delete it and use the new /Users/me/Library/org.swift.swiftpm/configuration/collections.json instead. > > I don't mind deleting that file, but will it mess up my Xcode 13 builds?

Boris B (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:22:47

*Thread Reply:* The message showing up multiple times is a known issue in Xcode 14 beta 1. This file contains the list of configured package collections, deleting it will only affect which package collections are visible during ‚ÄúAdd Package‚Äù, so it is safe to delete it. The warning is there to make you aware that a collection added using Xcode 14 will not appear in earlier versions and vice versa. So it is also safe to ignore the warning until you‚Äôre using Xcode 14 exclusively.

Artyom
2022-06-09 00:25:52

*Thread Reply:* @Boris B (Apple) So, is it correct that collections.json was copied to a new location thus the old one can be deleted or shall any additional changes be made to preserve existing packages collections?

Boris B (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:26:49

*Thread Reply:* Yes, that is correct. This is part of a one-time reorganization of these configuration files.

üôá Artyom
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 00:23:40

@Artyom asked > With this gorgeous Build Timeline I'm really curious if there are any advices on how to display the dependency graph for a Swift Package. The idea can be described as a diagram with displays how targets depend on one another. > I've been working on a pet-project tool to display it with some solutions that do not look quite right since the Package is a struct and it has targets property and SPM does package resolution anyway. Sooo, I've been wondering maybe there is some approach that I do not know about? üòÖ What would be your general advices to achieve such a behaviour? > > (And once again, Build Timeline is magnificent, many thanks for that, basically a piece of art)

‚ù§Ô∏è Ben H (Apple)
Anders B (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:24:51

*Thread Reply:* This is a great idea ‚Äî please file feedback at http://feedbackassistant.apple.com describing what information you would want to see in such a graph in Xcode.

For a pet project, one approach that might be useful would be to invoke swift package describe --type json to get structured output for each package (including target dependencies), and then to use that to construct a graph. There should be enough information there to represent all the dependencies.

Artyom
2022-06-09 00:27:42

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, parsing JSON is exactly the approach that made from prototype to some actual use üòÖ Thank you, I‚Äôll file a feedback then üôå

Ben H (Apple)
2022-06-09 02:59:02

*Thread Reply:* Hey @Artyom, sorry just got in. Awesome that the build timeline is helping you, that's really great to see! For the target dependency graph of a Swift package, that actually exists: swift package show-dependencies --format json. Does that miss anything you're looking for?

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 00:24:29

@Nikita asked > Is it possible to build an iOS app with SPM only without xcworkspace / xcproject and without falling back to generating one?

Andrew C (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:24:51

*Thread Reply:* Yes, it‚Äôs possible! In Xcode, choose File > New > Project‚Ä¶ and pick the Swift Playgrounds App template. These types of apps use the SwiftPM format rather than Xcode-style settings, so you‚Äôll get a Package.swift file instead of an xcodproj.

You could even use the Swift Playgrounds app on iPadOS for this! Here‚Äôs a guide to get you started in that direction if you want.

Playground App format is a good first step for replacing a heavy xcodeproj files to something modern. But we don‚Äôt have enough tools for that.

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 00:34:39

@Jeffrey asked > Can you help me with a crash with XcodePreview ? When I try to load an asset that is located in another package it crashes. Will it be possible to load assets from other local package ? > > https://forums.swift.org/t/xcode-previews-swiftpm-resources-xcpreviewagent-crashed/51680 > https://stackoverflow.com/q/64540082 > https://feedbackassistant.apple.com/feedback/10102512 > https://feedbackassistant.apple.com/feedback/10104291

Swift Forums
Xcode Previews + SwiftPM resources - XCPreviewAgent crashed
Hello all, There's a really frustrating crash with Xcode Previews because it cannot find the design resources package using the Bundle.module accessor (filed FB9479423). Is there something wrong with the package setup? I have some Swift packages dependent on another package containing design resources. Xcode Previews do not work because XCPreviewAgent crashes: CompanyDesign/resource_bundle_accessor.swift:27: Fatal error: unable to find bundle named CompanyDesign_CompanyDesign Is there some o...
Reading time
2 mins üïë
Likes
18 ‚ù§Ô∏è
Original URL: https://forums.swift.org/t/xcode-previews-swiftpm-resources-xcpreviewagent-crashed/51680
Stack Overflow
Xcode 12 - SwiftUI preview doesn't work on Swift Package when have another Swift Package as dependencies - 'previewInstances' message to agent
I have an issue on SwiftUI preview in a view located in a Swift Package when my code imports a control or value from an other swift package. import Foundation import SwiftUI import Common struct
Original URL: https://stackoverflow.com/q/64540082
Boris B (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:35:07

*Thread Reply:* This is a known issue when using resources of transitive dependencies while previewing a standalone package. Using an app as the preview host as discussed in the forum thread is the recommended workaround at the moment.

Jeffrey
2022-06-09 00:45:39

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for taking the time to respond. I‚Äôm more confident now that this bug will be fixed. I‚Äôm not really sure what this(Using an app as the preview host) means. Because when I select the app and run the Preview it doesn‚Äôt crash but nothing seems to be happening. DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 00:36:49

@Brandon asked > What is your advice for handling teams where some developers are on Intel machines and some on Apple Silicon? We run Xcode through Rosetta consistently, but wondering if you had best practices.

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:37:19

*Thread Reply:* Hi Brandon, I'd be interested in understanding your team's use case for running Xcode under Rosetta

Andrew H (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:39:41

*Thread Reply:* ~Guessing this is they produce Intel Debug builds? (which would run on all systems)~

Brandon
2022-06-09 00:41:40

*Thread Reply:* @Ryan B (Apple) We have some internal, third-party dependencies that throw an Unsupported Swift architecture and Could not build Objective-C module... when running without Rosetta. Our builds typically go through a CI pipeline, so there's little need for actually using Rosetta if there was an easy way of resolving the aforementioned errors, assuming we could run Xcode on both Intel and Apple Silicon machines.

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:42:42

*Thread Reply:* Are these internal dependencies fat binaries that have slices for both Intel and Apple silicon?

Brandon
2022-06-09 00:43:57

*Thread Reply:* @Ryan B (Apple) Regretfully, your question goes a bit over my head, so I can't say with confidence. If you have guidance or documentation on where to look into this, I can start investigating and speak with the teams responsible for said dependency.

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:44:50

*Thread Reply:* Let's start simple: what platforms do your app build for?

Brandon
2022-06-09 00:46:20

*Thread Reply:* Our app is iPhone (iOS 13+) only. Our internal developers work on macOS 12, all of us on Xcode 13.4.1, as noted some on Intel, some on Apple Silicon.

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:48:01

*Thread Reply:* Do you have the "excluded architectures" build setting set in your project?

Brandon
2022-06-09 00:48:54

*Thread Reply:* Excellent question; I was just exploring that area before this Q&A started. Yes, to your question. We have arm64 listed for each scheme next to "Any iOS Simulator SDK".

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:49:46

*Thread Reply:* Well, I'm guessing that's your problem. You have set Xcode to build only for Intel

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:50:57

*Thread Reply:* If you run Xcode without Rosetta, then the current architecture will be arm64, but you have set Xcode not to build for that architecture

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:51:31

*Thread Reply:* Hence why you have found you need to run under Rosetta

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:52:21

*Thread Reply:* We strongly suggest not excluding architectures and instead building your app for every supported CPU type

Brandon
2022-06-09 00:53:46

*Thread Reply:* To that end (and totally understand we're deep-diving here, so I know you might only be able to help so far - thank you for this so far), if I remove arm64 from the Excluded Architectures, I end up with a familiar ...building for iOS Simulator, but linking object file built for iOS...for architecture arm64 (this with Rosetta disabled and running Xcode 14 natively).

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:55:34

*Thread Reply:* The iOS simulator and iOS on-device are two distinct platforms, even though they may share a CPU architecture (arm64). You need to make sure that your dependency is configured to build with both native (device) and Simulator slices

Brandon
2022-06-09 00:56:42

*Thread Reply:* Got it, that makes sense. Last question, if you don't mind, but do you have any guidance on where I can turn to learn more about what slices my dependency is designed to build for? This is a little outside of my wheel house, but I'm sure with some guidance, I can figure it out and learn what steps are needed.

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:59:09

*Thread Reply:* Do you have the source for this dependency, or are you building (linking) against a pre-compiled library?

Brandon
2022-06-09 01:00:24

*Thread Reply:* I have the source. It's an internal dependency that I can view/modify as needed üôÇ

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:04:46

*Thread Reply:* The first thing I would do is read this documentation page: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/apple-silicon/building-a-universal-macos-binary

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:10:23

*Thread Reply:* I strongly suggest not running Xcode under Rosetta. This tends to mask issues in your project configuration. Instead, have Xcode build for all architectures, at least for release builds. Since no iOS device runs on Intel, the fact that you have to compile for Intel suggests to me that your app's code is not properly set up to support Simulator. You might be hard-coding a particular architecture or SDK somewhere in your project

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:11:08

*Thread Reply:* Unfortunately, I don't think I can help you much further over Slack. You should check if there are any more lab sessions available, or try posting on the developer forums

Brandon
2022-06-09 01:11:52

*Thread Reply:* Got it; thank you @Ryan B (Apple). Again, this goes a bit over my head, but I'm grateful for your help. Our core app and dependencies only run on iOS, so I'm not sure why we'd need to support Intel. I will connect with the developers of the dependency in question, but will also schedule a lab if times exist as I know our team would be thrilled to get our own building not just on Xcode 14, but natively on Apple Silicon, as well.

Brandon
2022-06-09 01:12:00

*Thread Reply:* Thanks so much for your in-depth troubleshooting!

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:13:26

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, I suspect that your project's Simulator configuration had a hard dependency on compiling on Intel, and when Apple silicon came around, someone just ran Xcode through Rosetta (which you really, really, really should not do) instead of fixing the underlying issue

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:13:41

*Thread Reply:* And no problem at all! We are happy to help; it's what we are here for!

Brandon
2022-06-09 01:34:47

*Thread Reply:* Thanks so much for all of the help! Greatly, greatly appreciated!

üòÅ Ryan B (Apple)
üî® Andrew C (Apple)
Duncan
2022-06-09 01:35:04

*Thread Reply:* I experienced the exact issue above with my app‚Äôs OpenSSL dependency as soon as I moved to Apple Silicon. The final step in the solution was realising that while you can compile a single static library that contains both the arm64 code for running on iOS and also the arm64 code for running on the Simulator on an Apple Silicon Mac, as far as I‚Äôm aware Xcode will not/cannot select the simulator version of the fat binary when building the app to run on the Simulator.

The solution instead was to package the dependency in Frameworks, containing separate universal libraries for Simulator vs Device, and so will vend the correct required code in each environment. In my case, someone else had already written a tool to package OpenSSL that way, which made my life easier, but it was uncovering the need to do this that was the breakthrough. Sounds like you‚Äôre describing the exact same scenario to me.

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:38:22

*Thread Reply:* I'm going to second Duncan's suggestion here. If you have not looked into XCFrameworks, now is a great time to do so!

üëç Michael
Duncan
2022-06-09 01:39:09

*Thread Reply:* Example: https://github.com/jasonacox/Build-OpenSSL-cURL

GitHub
GitHub - jasonacox/Build-OpenSSL-cURL: Scripts to build OpenSSL, HTTP/2 (nghttp2) and cURL (libcurl) for MacOS, iOS and tvOS devices (x86_64, armv7, armv7s, arm64, arm64e). Now Supporting Apple Silicon, OpenSSL 1.1.1 with TLS 1.3 and Mac Catalyst builds.
Scripts to build OpenSSL, HTTP/2 (nghttp2) and cURL (libcurl) for MacOS, iOS and tvOS devices (x86_64, armv7, armv7s, arm64, arm64e). Now Supporting Apple Silicon, OpenSSL 1.1.1 with TLS 1.3 and Ma...
Original URL: https://github.com/jasonacox/Build-OpenSSL-cURL
Brandon
2022-06-09 01:39:38

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the detail, @Duncan @Ryan B (Apple). So much of this is handled outside of my own purview, similar to your OpenSSL experience, @Duncan, that I have a bit of a learning curve ahead of me to understand how to implement this. But it is critically important to me, and my team, to get our app running natively on Apple Silicon (and Xcode 14, for that matter), so these challenges are worth learning and overcoming.

Duncan
2022-06-09 01:42:01

*Thread Reply:* There is a lot of work in that repo and setting up the XCFrameworks you need is likely to be a lot simpler than producing something like that! The key point is the XCFramework packaging that lets you vend the correct version of your dependency for the two environments. You got this. üëç:skintone3:

Brandon
2022-06-09 01:43:16

*Thread Reply:* Thanks, @Duncan! I appreciate the vote of confidence and will be checking that out now! I am going to get to the bottom of it!

Anders B (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:38:21

*Thread Reply:* We would very much like to know more about the errors you are encountering. There should be no problem having just a plugin target, and a corresponding package product shouldn't be needed unless the plugin is used outside of the package.

If a clean build was needed in order to get the plugin to work, that sounds like a bug. It doesn't sound as if there is anything wrong with the setup.

If you have the time, would you want to make an appointment for the Xcode Open Hours Lab from 1pm-4pm on Friday? Alternatively, a bug report at https://feedbackassistant.apple.com with as much detail as you can provide would be greatly appreciated.

  3. I do not see the error in the Issue navigator or in status bar, but if I go to Report navigator, select failed build and check the errors there Also, when:

2022-06-09 01:01:10

2022-06-09 00:42:51

@Ken asked > Hi! In preparation for WWDC, we updated all our app release branches to build with Xcode 13.4! This went fine for most of our apps' branches, but one of those branches (with IPHONEOS_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET = 14.0) started producing archive builds which fail to upload to App Store Connect. The error we're getting is: > > &gt; ITMS-90427: Invalid Swift Support &gt; &gt; ‚Ä¶ &gt; &gt; We identified one or more issues with a recent delivery for your app, "OmniFocus 3 Enterprise" 3.13 (151.23.24). Please correct the following issues, then upload again. &gt; &gt; ITMS-90427: Invalid Swift Support - The expected dylibs are missing from the app‚Äôs Framework location, such as /Payload/OmniFocus.app/Frameworks. &gt; > > Going back through builds of Xcode, it looks like this error started with Xcode 13.3, and seems to be associated with its bundling of: > > &gt; SwiftSupport/iphoneos/libswift_Concurrency.dylib &gt; > > We don't actually reference libswift_Concurrency.dylib in this release branch at all, so as far as we know we shouldn't need that dylib. But is there something we can do to make App Store Connect accept our upload (other than reverting to Xcode 13.2 or earlier)?

David O (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:43:53

*Thread Reply:* The libswift_Concurrency.dylib is a backwards compatibility library that is necessary when using Swift's async functionality when deploying to a platform that does not support concurrency natively. Are you removing this library from your app bundle?

We will likely need a feedback created that contains the build log for the archive process of your app to see if there is an issue with this library being bundled correctly.

Ken
2022-06-09 00:46:09

*Thread Reply:* We're not removing the library from our app bundle, but it doesn't appear to ever get added (which seems reasonable, since none of the binaries included with our app link against it).

Ken
2022-06-09 00:46:49

*Thread Reply:* (We're not using any async functionality in this old release branch of our app.)

Ken
2022-06-09 00:48:23

*Thread Reply:* Writing up a feedback report now. Thanks!

Ken
2022-06-09 00:55:52

*Thread Reply:* Filed as FB10115173. Thanks again!

David O (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:58:22

*Thread Reply:* Thank you! I will make sure it is routed appropriately.

Shahla
2022-06-10 02:53:58

We did check the binary and the library is indeed there. Yet TestFlight is rejecting the build saying it's missing the concurrency library

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 00:44:51

@Enrico asked > I can understand newest versions of Xcode being picky about the minimum macOS version required to run, but why recent macOS version can‚Äôt run older versions of Xcode?

Jon H (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:45:38

*Thread Reply:* We want to ensure the best experience for our developers. We explicitly qualify each version of Xcode with the two most recent versions macOS. We don't qualify older Xcode's with newer versions of macOS, and want to ensure you don't run into problems using an unsupported configuration.

üòØ Michael

Artyom
2022-06-09 00:53:25

*Thread Reply:* There seems to be an issue with the way Xcode updates SPM stuff. In my experience deadblock are caused when dependency was added. Especially if it is not cached yet. Meanwhile, CLI works fine. No sure about Xcode 14.

I‚Äôd recommend having something like this at hand and run it after you switch branch where something in the dependancy graph changed. With Xcode closed, of course. xcodebuild -resolvePackageDependencies -scheme YourScheme -project YourProject.xcodeproj -configuration YourConfiguration

Jean
2022-06-09 01:01:20

*Thread Reply:* This link is very familiar to my issue: https://forums.swift.org/t/missing-package-product-error-for-all-local-swift-packages-when-switching-git-branches/38041

Swift Forums
"Missing package product" error for all local Swift Packages when switching git branches
I'm seeing a consistent Xcode error for all of my local swift packages when switching git branches or doing a git pull while Xcode is open. A workaround that works ~75% of the time: Kill xcode Then completely remove the derived data directory (empty trash just to be absolutely sure). Restart Xcode Reset Swift package cache On some occasions, this workaround fails and am forced to do a fresh git clone. Has anyone else seen this before? Xcode Version 11.5 (11E608c) swift-tools-version:5.2 ...

üôå Brian K (Apple)
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 00:52:40

@Todd asked > Deleting ~/Library/Developer/Xcode/DerivedData is a common workaround for various Xcode problems, at least according to community wisdom. Does this make Xcode engineers grit their teeth, and if so, what should we be doing instead?

Jon H (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:52:56

*Thread Reply:* When deleting your derived data fixes a problem, it means that there's a dependency in your sources that either Xcode doesn't see but should, or that you haven't declared. In either case, if you could isolate the problem and report it in feedback, we'd use that to improve Xcode.

üëç Michael, Wayne
Todd
2022-06-09 00:55:42

*Thread Reply:* Thank you, I will do that!

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 01:02:55

@Jordan asked > I recall it used to be you could not use a beta macOS version and the current public version of Xcode to distribute an app on the App Store. Is that still the case? Recognizing the current macOS beta doesn't support the public Xcode, it's not super relevant right now, but still curious if this remains true.

Itai R (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:03:10

*Thread Reply:* Xcode 13 will not run on macOS Ventura, There is no restriction on distributing apps to the App Store that were built with released tools on a beta macOS. However, we recommend using a released macOS whenever you build software that you intend to distribute.

üëç Jordan
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 01:06:39

@Ethan asked > I am using gRPC is there a way to monitor all the active gRPC connections? Not sure how accurate is the Active connection in the network report is.

Juan L (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:07:01

*Thread Reply:* The network gauge in the debug navigator shows a list of all the active connections. You can see the local and remote addresses and ports, state and the traffic for each connection. The data you see there should be accurate, if that‚Äôs not the case, please send us a feedback!

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 01:06:53

@Amir asked > Running a macOS catalyst app in Xcode in release mode creates two builds even though only one build is needed. This doubles the compile time. Any chance this could be fixed without affecting archive release builds?

Ben B (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:07:22

*Thread Reply:* Using generic run destinations will always build for all architectures, and because archiving can only be done with a generic run destinations, it will always build for all architectures. If you want to build for only the device's architecture in Release, you can do so by setting ONLY_ACTIVE_ARCH to YES for that (or all) configurations - it's set by default for Debug. This will not impact archiving.

Amir
2022-06-09 01:09:20

*Thread Reply:* So why isn‚Äôt this done by default given that archiving would not be affected?

Ben B (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:26:23

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the feedback! If you could file feedback at http://feedbackassistant.apple.com and post the FB number here, we'd really appreciate it.

Amir
2022-06-09 02:05:46

*Thread Reply:* Done. https://feedbackassistant.apple.com/feedback/10116446

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 01:07:20

@Adam asked > This came up in a lab today with Anders and he said to post here: > > Tickets: > > FB10107786 > FB10107712 > > Is there currently any way to flip on the ‚Äúthis is extension safe‚Äù bit when building a Dylib entirely in SPM?

Anders B (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:07:48

*Thread Reply:* There is currently no way to set the "extension safe" bit when building dynamic libraries from packages.

Thank you very much for providing the FB number here for that issue and for the bug with the conditional dependencies so that we can track them.

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 01:17:06

@Nathan asked > I didn't want to derail another thread about differences between Xcode running on Apple Silicon vs. Intel: the main problem we face are snapshot tests that produce slightly different results when executed on simulators running on AS vs. Intel. (These tend to be sub-pixel differences in the rendered output). Are you aware of any way we can launch simulators to mitigate these differences?

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:18:23

*Thread Reply:* Hi Nathan. I'm not aware of any specific reason why running on Intel vs on Apple silicon would produce differences in the rendered output. You may want to check if your app is doing some kind of conditional compilation of code that might be affecting the layout or the rendering

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:19:49

*Thread Reply:* Barring that, I think this would be a bug that our OS teams would be very interested in looking at. You can use Feedback Assistant to file the bug report. A sample project that reproduces the particular issue, alongside with a description of your hardware, would be helpful

Michal
2022-06-09 01:20:00

*Thread Reply:* We faced this as well and basically ended up keeping everything related to snapshots to our CIs ‚Äì so that only CI machines generate & validate snapshots during the acceptance pipeline.

Nikita
2022-06-09 01:20:53

*Thread Reply:* Curious what could be a reason. Can CPU architecture introduce different rounding issues that as result will produce subtle pixel differences in snapshots?

‚òùÔ∏è Michal
Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:21:48

*Thread Reply:* Yes, floating-point operations on different CPUs could be a potential source

‚òùÔ∏è Michal
üëç Michael
Nathan
2022-06-09 01:24:06

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the reply! I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs in our code because it‚Äôs reproducible on pretty trivial labels, but happy to check. There are a few discussions in snapshot libraries

It‚Äôs also an issue that impacts Android Emulators so it‚Äôs definitely a problem much closer to the CPU! I guess I was wondering if there are potentially some secret render flags when instantiating a simulator that might trigger a different codepath. Happy to file a FB with the OS teams

Nikita
2022-06-09 01:25:16

*Thread Reply:* This would be a legit use of precision in snapshot testing configuration, the same as where you compare two floats you do not compare them all way in. Most of snapshot test frameworks do have an option to configure precision. Setting something like 0.99 probably will solve the problem without allowing any significant degradations to sneak in.

Nikita
2022-06-09 01:25:53

*Thread Reply:* None

Screen Shot 2022-06-08 at 4.25.39 PM.png
Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:26:39

*Thread Reply:* I was going to say essentially what Nikita said -- due to the nature of floating point operations, especially across CPU architectures, you can't really do a straight binary diff to determine whether things have changed. You need to choose a threshold for acceptable differences (deltas)

Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:28:30

*Thread Reply:* With regard to any "secret render flags" -- that's a great question for the OS teams, but I think what they will tell you is that you won't always get 100% perfect output, and you need to decide what level of difference between two screenshots you are willing to tolerate

Nathan
2022-06-09 01:29:54

*Thread Reply:* We‚Äôve seen some very high precision deltas sometimes (> 10%) that would effectively make the tests useless, sadly. Though yes, in general, the libraries seem to be evolving so that they can quantify the difference between two pixels with more nuance than just being a match or not.

‚ÅâÔ∏è Duncan
Ryan B (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:32:28

*Thread Reply:* Is it possible for you to standardize on a specific platform and CPU for taking the snapshots?

Nathan
2022-06-09 01:34:20

*Thread Reply:* Sure. At the moment anyone with an M1 asks someone on an Intel mac to update their PR with the snapshot tests üôÇ

üòÖ Michal, Roland, omar
Iain
2022-06-09 09:46:43

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for discussing this, we also are facing this issue in a team with mixed machines.

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 01:19:05

@Enrico asked > With TestFlight being an iOS 13+ app, how can I distribute my beta builds to users on iOS 12 which we are still supporting?

Itai R (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:19:18

*Thread Reply:* You can submit an app with an iOS 12 deployment target to TestFlight. In order to install the TestFlight client on devices with an older OS, you'll need to install a previous version from the Purchased list available in the App Store client.

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 01:20:29

@Craig asked > I've heard mixed reports about bitcode being deprecated for all platforms vs just watchOS and tvOS. Could you clarify which platforms bitcode has been deprecated for? Also, is it right that a target will just need BITCODE_ENABLED set to NO.

Itai R (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:21:15

*Thread Reply:* Bitcode is deprecated for all platforms. You can set BITCODE_ENABLED to NO in your projects to disable building with it. Xcode will also automatically compile bitcode into machine code when you upload your app to App Store Connect.

üëç Michael, Max, Raphael

@Phillip asked > Hi Guys, hopefully a simple question. In 13+ many times when I debug and try to see the values in variables it since they have been optimized out. Is there a way that this will not be done while debugging? I can t figure out what causes it and or iof there is a switch to stop this behaviour.

Juan L (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:25:01

*Thread Reply:* This could happen because the debugger doesn‚Äôt have the symbols to read a particular variable from memory. We made a lot of improvements this year when it comes to the variables view in Xcode 14 and lldb. If you can isolate problems like these, please send us a feedback with a sample project!

Jim I (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:37:03

*Thread Reply:* You've probably done this already, but do make sure that the SWIFTOPTIMIZATIONLEVEL setting in your project is set to none in the build you are trying to debug. Debugging optimized Swift code is not supported at present.

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 01:30:53

@Al asked > Is it normal to see multiple "Resolve Packages" tasks in the Report navigator when opening a project with lots of SPM dependencies? If so, why?

Anders B (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:31:16

*Thread Reply:* This is not normally expected. Are you seeing any warnings or other messages in the previous Package Resolution logs?

It is also possible that something is causing a change to the files in the package that is triggering second package resolution after the first one completes.

Would you mind filing a bug report at feedbackassistant.apple.com with as much information as you can provide from the package resolution log?

Al
2022-06-09 01:32:33

*Thread Reply:* usually we don't see any issues when this happens, though occasionally authentication fails to a git repo with private dependencies

Al
2022-06-09 01:32:42

*Thread Reply:* i'll file a feedback though, yes

Michal
2022-06-09 01:33:25

*Thread Reply:* In my case, this is triggered when opening a Swift package directly, having DerivedData folder set to be placed relatively, that means, inside the package folder. üí• Just to put another reproduction way here. üëå

Anders B (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:34:13

*Thread Reply:* Thank you for the additional information. I think a bug report with as much information as you can share would be helpful. The part about the DerivedData folder is particularly interesting, and would suggest that it's the creation of intermediate package resolution files that's causing the reresolve.

üëç Al
Anders B (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:34:42

*Thread Reply:* There is provision for avoiding such a feedback loop, but it definitely sounds as if there is a bug here.

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 01:31:47

@Ricardo asked > Whats the recommended way to package up internal dependencies (ex: model-layer code, etc) in Xcode? Is it SPM or Frameworks?

Andrew C (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:32:02

*Thread Reply:* The answer to this will depend on your team and your needs. Packages will make it easier to break your dependencies up into smaller chunks, store them in separate repos, and version them independently ‚Äî but frameworks will give you things like advanced project customisation and Objective-C interoperability.

Carlos
2022-06-09 01:39:00

*Thread Reply:* Adding to this thread: if our framework uses Objective-C code, and users of the framework (customers) are asking us for a Swift package, can we give them what they want by bundling the framework as a binary wrapped in a Swift package?

ü§î Andrew C (Apple)
Carlos
2022-06-09 01:51:02

*Thread Reply:* Reposted my question in its own thread in case this thread is marked as already answered‚Ä¶ apparently cannot delete here.

Andrew C (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:51:47

*Thread Reply:* No worries ‚Äî that will definitely get more eyeballs on your question!

Duncan
2022-06-09 02:01:39

*Thread Reply:* @Carlos not sure if your reposted question got answered in the end, so just coming back here to comment: I was really surprised to discover a while back that you can actually vend a mixture of Swift and Objective-C code in a single Swift Package. If the situation hasn‚Äôt changed, each target within the Package can only be Swift or Objective-C. But you can put your Objective-C classes in a single target, and make that an internal dependency of your Swift library. So all up, the point is you don‚Äôt have to bundle it as a binary if you don‚Äôt want to, in order to give your customers the Swift package.

Maybe this isn‚Äôt what you were asking‚Ä¶ but just in case it was.

My use case was because I needed to include a helper class in Objective-C to call an iOS API that currently cannot be called from Swift, only from Objective-C. (Weird.)

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 01:32:58

@Craig asked > We've got an app that's split up into many frameworks. There's a single project that contains all the targets. I've seen examples of apps that make multiple single-target projects in a workspace. Other than organization, is there any difference between those two approaches or are they functionally the same.

Jon H (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:33:17

*Thread Reply:* The two arrangements support the same features. If you'd like to open subsets of the projects without seeing all of the sources, you might prefer the organization with multiple project files.

For example, if you later have two top level apps that use different subsets of the targets, they can each have a more focused workspace with the many projects approach.

üëç Michael, Karim
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 01:39:10

Boris B (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:39:21

*Thread Reply:* If you take the xcodebuild command from the Resolve package dependencies step of your Xcode Cloud logs and add the option -IDEPackageOnlyUseVersionsFromResolvedFile=YES, can you reproduce the issue locally?

Boris B (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:55:54

*Thread Reply:* Alternatively, feel free to submit a bug report at https://feedbackassistant.apple.com

Ethan
2022-06-09 01:57:20

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 01:53:37

@Vladislav asked > Are planning to add support ‚ÄúSigning and Run locally‚Äù to iOS targets?

Itai R (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:53:49

*Thread Reply:* iOS requires apps to be signed with a trusted certificate in order to install and run.

Vladislav
2022-06-09 01:55:59

*Thread Reply:* The macOS runtime environment differs substantially from iOS. However, if this is something that would benefit your work we'd welcome a feedback report with more details.

üòÆ Vladislav
‚ù§Ô∏è Vladislav
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 01:53:38

@Ashton asked > The new primary associated types are really cool. I immediately tried it with Publisher eg: some Publisher&lt;String, Never&gt; but found this protocol does not support this. > I've read SE-0358 but I'm still not clear on why this protocol shouldn't or couldn't use this new feature?

Robert W (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:53:59

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for your interest in using Combine with primary associated types. We share your excitement, and think this would be a great direction forward. Please file feedback at https://feedbackassistant.apple.com against Combine to add this as an enhancement.

üì° Ashton, Shai
‚úÖ Ashton
Robert W (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:56:42

*Thread Reply:* To answer your question, there is nothing stopping Combine from adopting this feature. You can even try it out yourself if you want to by defining your own protocol that refines Publisher and making combines existing publisher types conform to it.

```protocol _Publisher<Output, Failure>: Combine.Publisher { associatedtype Output associatedtype Failure }

extension Just: _Publisher {} /* etc */``` It's a bit tedious but each conformance should take no code outside of the extension.

üôå Ashton, Iain
Jacob I (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:55:03

Our time for the Xcode Open Hours is wrapping up - thanks for coming!

We got lots of questions and may not have been able to answer all of them. If your question didn't get answered, you can check to see if there are other Developer Tools Sessions, Labs, or Lounges that might be better suited to your questions. For topics not covered there, you can also post your questions in the Developer Forums.

üåê Andrew C (Apple)
üôè Joseph, Nikita
üò• Michal, ÍπÄ
üôå Nathan, Nikita, Tyler
‚ù§Ô∏è Akito, Nikita, Arnaud, Artyom, Philippe
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 02:00:21

@Carlos asked > If our framework uses Objective-C code, and users of the framework (customers) are asking us for a Swift package, can we give them what they want by bundling the framework as a binary wrapped in a Swift package?

Anders B (Apple)
2022-06-09 02:00:31

*Thread Reply:* Swift Packages can contain targets that are comprised of C or Objective-C code and that are compiled with the Clang compiler. If the Objective-C target has modularized headers and does not require special compiler options that are not supported by Swift Package, then a good solution would be to build the library as a Swift Package with an Objective-C target.

‚òÅÔ∏è Martin
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 18:08:44

@Mykyta asked > We‚Äôre building a location tracking app that collects user locations in background and periodically sends them to our backend for further processing. It‚Äôs important for us that the app is as power efficient as possible. Which means 1. optimizing location data collecting 2. network usage optimization (choosing the right network protocol/time intervals and so on). > > The question is what‚Äôs the best way to test different location/network settings for power consumption? Is there a way to measure device power consumption in mA or watts? > > We tried using xCode‚Äôs energy impact gauge, but it doesn‚Äôt give enough precision to distinguish between different CLLocationManager settings. We also tried running tests on a physical device and see what battery drainage per hour is. But it‚Äôs terribly inefficient and the results are not as precise as we would like them to be.

Ethan V (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:10:32

*Thread Reply:* Hi Mykyta! I'd recommend that you ask this question in the "Performance, power, and stability lab" tomorrow, as the folks there should have some good recommendations for your use cases. I'd also recommend checking out the WWDC19 session "Designing for Adverse Network and Temperature Conditions". As that session will explain, it's possible to use Xcode to simulate adverse network conditions, which may be useful in this case.

üëç Mykyta
Ryan
2022-06-09 18:56:25

*Thread Reply:* @Mykyta I‚Äôd also be interested in what you are able to find out from the Performance, Power and Stability lab as these are important things we are attempting to inspect and evaluate as well.

Daniel D (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:27:54

*Thread Reply:* Instruments has a Location Energy Model tool in the library that you can use to track your CoreLocation precision usage over time. This is helpful because as you point out, the best way to manage the power usage from your code is with the location manager settings.

Measuring actual power drain is much more complicated, as there are a myriad of factors ‚Äî device model, network conditions, other device services, temperature, etc. and it's hard to measure precisely in live debugging conditions or predict/extrapolate to what users will experience when they're out and about in different conditions. MetricKit can help with the aggregate statistics though to show you usage trends over time,

üëç Mykyta
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 18:14:12

@Ethan asked > When managing workflow for Xcode Cloud the scheme I selected have a yellow exclamation mark saying "The scheme may only exist locally". I am pretty sure this scheme have shared checked and the xcsharedata folder is in the repo. I am wondering is because of the having this exclamation mark my xcode cloud build always failed with message "An internal error has occurred. This operation will be retried on another build worker"

Billy C (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:14:23

*Thread Reply:* The warning that ‚Äúthe scheme may only exist locally‚Äù shows up if you configure a workflow with a scheme that Xcode Cloud has never seen in a cloud build. Every time we run a build we record what public schemes were in your project. If you add a new scheme in a commit, Xcode on your machine knows about it but our servers don‚Äôt. You can go ahead and change the workflow anyways, it‚Äôs just warning you that builds might fail on branches that don‚Äôt have the scheme.

As for the ‚Äúan internal error occurred message,‚Äù please file a feedback with a link to the build. It might be the cause of the warning, if there‚Äôs a failure before we record the schemes.

Ethan
2022-06-09 18:16:08

*Thread Reply:* Now I keep getting "Could not resolve package dependencies" error. executing the same command in local is fine

Ethan
2022-06-09 18:17:21

*Thread Reply:* I added -IDEPackageOnlyUseVersionsFromResolvedFile=YES suggested by Boris yesterday to run it locally and is running fine as well

Billy C (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:19:20

*Thread Reply:* The most common cause of package dependency issues is if Xcode Cloud can't access the package.resolved file in your repo, see https://developer.apple.com/documentation/xcode/making-dependencies-available-to-xcode-cloud#Use-Swift-package-dependencies-and-Git-submodules If that command is working locally, it means the file is available locally, but make sure it's checked in as well.

Ethan
2022-06-09 18:20:27

*Thread Reply:* Yes, I am 100% sure it's checked in.

Ethan
2022-06-09 18:26:33

*Thread Reply:* Okay I just double check I think it didn't get checked in. Thanks for the help

Billy C (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:26:52

*Thread Reply:* Glad that helped!

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 18:19:22

@Lawrence asked > When adding [ci skip] in my commit for Xcode Cloud, will this string also appear in our GitHub repository?

Brian C (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:19:42

*Thread Reply:* Yes, the full content of your commit message, including the [ci skip] tag, will be present in your repository.

Brian C (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:20:08

*Thread Reply:* Xcode Cloud reads the content of the commit message, but it cannot filter or modify it.

Lawrence
2022-06-09 18:22:53

*Thread Reply:* I see, makes sense. Thanks for answering.

@Todd asked > Hello! My team is very interested in switching to Xcode Cloud for CI/CD. Tevin M (Apple)

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 18:25:19

@Gaige B. asked > What's a reasonable expectation on the backwards compatibility for xctestrun? I'm creating mostly macOS apps, and I need to keep a couple of versions of macOS supported to keep with my users. Right now (Xcode 13.4), I can use buildfortesting and testwithoutbuilding to test under macOS 11 and macOS 12, but not macOS 10.15 (our oldest supported version. Going forward, what can we expect for backwards testing compatibility?

Ethan V (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:25:36

*Thread Reply:* Regardless of the project's deployment target, the products of build-for-testing are only valid for testing on macOS versions that are supported by the Xcode that produced those products.

Gaige B.
2022-06-09 18:26:37

*Thread Reply:* Is there any indication which versions are supported by Xcode for Xcode 14?

Ethan V (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:27:03

*Thread Reply:* Since you'd like to test older macOS versions than the ones that are supported by the Xcode that's producing the test build products, could you file a feedback assistant requesting this capability?

üëç Gaige B.
‚úÖ Gaige B.
Ethan V (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:28:37

*Thread Reply:* Xcode 14 is supported on macOS 12.4 and later.

Gaige B.
2022-06-09 18:31:20

*Thread Reply:* It would be helpful to have test-without-building support os versions that represent a substantial portion of the customer population. For iOS, it's easy to expect people to move forward, because of the high percentage of users who move forward annually. I don't see the stats published by Apple, but from our customers we don't see the same quick adoption on macOS. (Yes, I'll put that in the feedback).

üëç Ethan V (Apple)
Ethan V (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:54:09

*Thread Reply:* The use case of testing older macOS versions is definitely valid, and it's awesome that you are focused on expanding your test coverage across various OS versions. Your feedback here will help us prioritize our offerings in this area for the future!

2022-06-09 18:34:59

2022-06-09 18:51:34

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 18:31:14

@Adrian asked > How do Xcode Cloud and Xcode Server "relate to" and "work with" each other? Would it make sense to have an Xcode Server setup for small/PoC projects/teams and an Xcode Cloud setup for bigger/productive projects/teams? Would it be easy to move projects and configuration files between Xcode Cloud and (on premise) Xcode Server? In case this would indeed be an option, is there any documentation how to best practice such a dual CI/CD setup approach?

‚úÖ Thomas
Honza D (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:31:20

*Thread Reply:* Xcode Server has been deprecated this year, see https://developer.apple.com/documentation/xcode-release-notes/xcode-14-release-notes. We encourage developers to try out Xcode Cloud. If you find functionality missing from Xcode Cloud that was present in Xcode Server, please file a feedback.

üëÄ Adrian
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 18:31:21

@Nathan asked > Is Xcode Cloud available for enterprise apps?

Itai R (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:31:30

*Thread Reply:* Xcode Cloud is not available for the Apple Developer Enterprise Program. If this is a feature you'd like to see in the future, we'd welcome a feedback report from you.

Myke S (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:34:49

*Thread Reply:* feedbackassistant.apple.com

Itai R (Apple)
2022-06-10 19:58:12

*Thread Reply:* Also I should mention that cloud signing, which is available in both Xcode Cloud and in Xcode, does support enterprise apps. So you can export your apps from Xcode's Organizer and take advantage of cloud managed signing certificates, just like Xcode Cloud uses.

Itai R (Apple)
2022-06-10 19:59:02

*Thread Reply:* You can learn more about that in Distribute apps in Xcode with cloud signing from WWDC21.

Apple Developer
Distribute apps in Xcode with cloud signing - WWDC21 - Videos - Apple Developer
Discover how to distribute your apps directly to App Store Connect and all the distribution methods supported in Xcode. Explore how to...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2021/10204
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 18:35:39

@Braden asked > Will/does Xcode Cloud have the ability to auto-update signing certificates when they will expire?

Itai R (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:35:45

*Thread Reply:* Xcode Cloud uses cloud signing certificates that it automatically manages on your behalf. It will renew certificates a few months before they expire so that your builds have valid signatures while you test and distribute them.

2022-06-09 18:45:02

@ChakMing asked > If I used Xcode Cloud to build the app, do I still need to adjust the build number in the future? Or just leave it as 1 is fine?

Itai R (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:46:00

*Thread Reply:* Xcode Cloud can manage your build number for you. For a new app, you can leave the build number at 1. If you have an existing app, we suggest reading this documentation for more information about how Xcode Cloud manages build numbers.

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 18:49:56

@Sara asked > Does Xcode Cloud integrate with other CI/CD workflows like Jenkins or is it considered standalone?

Ana C (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:50:03

*Thread Reply:* You can connect Xcode Cloud to other services using webhooks directly (https://developer.apple.com/documentation/xcode/configuring-webhooks-in-xcode-cloud), and Xcode Cloud is also part of the App Store Connect API (https://developer.apple.com/documentation/appstoreconnectapi/xcode_cloud_workflows_and_builds)

:gratitude_thank_you: Sara
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 18:50:22

@Braden asked > Can you integrate Xcode cloud with Fastlane?

Ana C (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:50:32

*Thread Reply:* You can connect Xcode Cloud to other services using webhooks: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/xcode/configuring-webhooks-in-xcode-cloud

If there's more behavior you'd like to see supported in Xcode Cloud for your development workflow, please file a Feedback report at http://feedbackassistant.apple.com.

Ana C (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:51:10

*Thread Reply:* Xcode Cloud is also part of the App Store Connect API (https://developer.apple.com/documentation/appstoreconnectapi/xcode_cloud_workflows_and_builds)

Ana C (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:04:35

*Thread Reply:* Alternatively, if you're trying to call Fastlane from Xcode Cloud, check out "Writing custom build scripts": https://developer.apple.com/documentation/xcode/writing-custom-build-scripts

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 18:56:17

@Sean asked > We have a large development organization with many apps and teams. > > I have two Xcode Cloud subscription questions: > > 1. What happens if we exceed 1000 hours of compute time a month? > > 2. Would it be possible to have multiple subscriptions, each for specific apps/teams?

Tevin M (Apple)
2022-06-09 18:57:13

*Thread Reply:* > 1. What happens if we exceed 1000 hours of compute time a month? Any builds in flight will complete, however no new builds will kick-off until the cycle resets on the "monthly anniversary" date.

> 2. Would it be possible to have multiple subscriptions, each for specific apps/teams? Subscriptions are per Developer team.

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:01:15

@Kyle asked > To build my project, I need to first build some tools using Mint (https://github.com/yonaskolb/Mint)|https://github.com/yonaskolb/Mint) such as swift-format and XcodeGen. This dramatically increases job times because the extra tools need to be rebuilt each run. Do you have any recommendations on how to reduce the time needed for this? Is there a way to cache custom directories created during the job such as ~/.mint (where Mint puts the built products) to re-use on subsequent jobs?

Ethan V (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:02:22

*Thread Reply:* One thing you could try here is to install these tools via homebrew in ci_pre_xcodebuild.sh, which is a script that runs prior to xcodebuild in Xcode Cloud (see the documentation here).

Kyle
2022-06-09 19:04:06

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the suggestion! We would, but Homebrew doesn‚Äôt let us control the version of the tool, we can only get the latest. We want to make sure all the devs & CI are using the same versions to avoid any inconsistencies üòÑ

Ethan V (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:11:01

*Thread Reply:* In that case, another option is to have the versions of the tools you need on some content storage, and then download those tools in ci_pre_xcodebuild.sh.

üëç Kyle
Kyle
2022-06-09 19:11:43

*Thread Reply:* @Ethan V (Apple) do you know if Swift Package plugins would possibly help with this? A lot of our caching use case has to do with tools related to code generation and linting/formatting. I haven‚Äôt had time to explore Package plugins yet, but I wonder if we could pull those tool dependencies into our app‚Äôs SPM dependencies, and write some Package plugins to execute them. At that point maybe the tools would be cached in DerivedData?

Most of the examples I‚Äôve seen for Package plugins seemed to execute a CLI tool though, not run other Swift code, so maybe this wouldn‚Äôt work ü§î

Ethan V (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:11:44

*Thread Reply:* If that also doesn't work, we recommend storing the build products in DerivedData. The contents of DerivedData should be cached for future runs. If you notice any issues with that, please file a feedback assistant!

2022-06-09 19:17:29

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:30:22

@Brandon asked > Is there a workflow that allows for manually building a build off of a specific branch? More specifically, if I had a feature branch and wanted to generate a build for a non-developer to test through TestFlight, is this possible?

Tevin M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:31:36

*Thread Reply:* Yes! You can create a workflow with an archive action and any start condition. To prevent the start condition from running and make the workflow only trigger manually, you can disable the workflow. Disabling the workflow will stop the start condition from working, but will still let you start builds manually. You can start a build manually by using the Start Build button. I realize that this flow is involved. Please file a feedback report with Feedback Assistant and provide feedback / suggestions for making this flow better.

:gratitude_thank_you: Brandon
Brandon
2022-06-09 19:33:48

*Thread Reply:* Thank you, @Tevin M (Apple)!

Tevin M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:39:26

*Thread Reply:* No problem. I hope you have a great rest of your day!

Brandon
2022-06-09 19:52:37

*Thread Reply:* You as well!

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:31:24

@Ethan asked > In Xcode cloud workflow there is an option to select Deployment preparation for internal or App Store. and In Post-Action it's also separate between internal and app store. My question is from my understand in Appstore connect dashboard there is only one place showing Testflight how is internal and appstore build being differentiate? or how can I tell which one is for internal or which one is for app store

Itai R (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:31:31

*Thread Reply:* If you want to check if an Xcode Cloud build is Internal Only or App Store Eligible, you can go to Build Groups tab > click on a build and check the Build Type field. Also, you will not be able to add any internal only builds to an external group, they will be disabled in the Add Build UI.

Ethan
2022-06-09 19:34:34

*Thread Reply:* Thanks. curious did this ever get mentioned in any document or session ?

Itai R (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:36:41

*Thread Reply:* Deploying to internal testers was covered in Explore Xcode Cloud workflows

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:32:16

@Ethan asked > I have a lot of extensions in our app so updating them for a new build requires going in to each one to update the version number and build number. Is there a way to automate this? using custom script?

Itai R (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:32:28

*Thread Reply:* When distributing your app from either Xcode or Xcode Cloud, the build numbers in your app and all of your app extensions will automatically be updated. For more information, watch Distribute apps in Xcode with cloud signing or check out this documentation for Xcode Cloud. You will still need to manage version numbers yourself, since those are more correlated to your own product release plans.

Apple Developer
Distribute apps in Xcode with cloud signing - WWDC21 - Videos - Apple Developer
Discover how to distribute your apps directly to App Store Connect and all the distribution methods supported in Xcode. Explore how to...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/wwdc21/10204

@Alexandre asked > When trying to set up Xcode Cloud for our iOS app containing private Swift packages, we see the error > > GitLab installation was incomplete. > Repository was not found. Either the repository does not exist or you do not have permission to access it. > > Is there something special to do for Xcode Cloud to get access to private Swift packages hosted on GitLab?

Honza D (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:53:02

*Thread Reply:* Please make sure to follow the steps described in connecting Xcode Cloud with GitLab (https://developer.apple.com/documentation/xcode/connecting-xcode-cloud-to-gitlab) or self-hosted GitLab (https://developer.apple.com/documentation/xcode/connecting-xcode-cloud-to-a-self-managed-gitlab-instance), depending on which one you're using.

For that, you need to be an admin of the repositories.

If the issue persists, please file a feedback at feedbackassistant.apple.com.

set the channel topic: Q&A: Performance, Power, and Stability

Tibet R (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:01:02

üëã Welcome to Q&A: Performance, Power, and Stability! We are so happy and excited to have you all here!! ü•≥

Thanks for keeping everything chill and refreshing yourself with our code of conduct!

For this activity, we‚Äôre looking forward to answering your questions through the Workflow built in to Slack.

How To Ask a Question:

  1. Select the Shortcuts button (‚ûïicon) from the lower left, and find the :workflowbolt:Ask a question workflow.
  2. Type in your question Your question will be delivered directly to us, and we‚Äôll repost and answer as many of them as we can.

Let‚Äôs kick it off! üéâ

Tibet R (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:18:39

What‚Äôs the silliest ü§£ one-line perf mistake you‚Äôve discovered by profiling your code? üßµ

Myke S (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:22:16

*Thread Reply:* I somehow keep mixing up the 2nd and 3rd arguments in a for loop which puts that into an infinite loop when you swap the condition checking with the incrementer.

üòÜ Tibet R (Apple)
‚ôæÔ∏è Jeff L (Apple), Jaanus
Itai R (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:26:40

*Thread Reply:* Early in my career I noticed a bug in our code when running in 64-bit. We used over 5x more memory to complete a simple task. Profiling our app easily turned up the issue ‚Äî someone had allocated a huge buffer to work around another 64-bit bug years earlier and had never removed it when the bug was fixed!

üòÜ Tibet R (Apple)
Daniel D (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:28:22

*Thread Reply:* Perhaps not the silliest, but always fun to discover -[x containsObject:] in a profile where x was actually an NSArray but was supposed to be an NSSet according to all of the surrounding code üôÇ

ü§≠ Tibet R (Apple)
Mike A (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:31:01

*Thread Reply:* I slightly messed an atomic increment recently which made the code always have to retry once before the increment succeeded. Somehow this displeased the CPU badly enough to make it run ~10x slower, not just 2x. The retry worked so it looked like everything was fine until I started timing it.

üòÇ Tibet R (Apple)
Ben M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:38:17

*Thread Reply:* I implemented a simple tree data structure, and scanning a given level of the tree should have taken linear time. Basic tests with a few entries worked fine. Once the app encountered real-world data, though, it became extremely slow. Instruments quickly showed me that each query was recursively descending through the whole tree, then throwing away everything. Oops -- accidentally quadratic!

üòÜ Tibet R (Apple)
Duncan
2022-06-09 20:40:04

*Thread Reply:* I mean‚Ä¶ it has to be dispatching something to the main thread that I didn‚Äôt mean to be there.

üòÇ Tibet R (Apple)
Tibet R (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:40:16

*Thread Reply:* So glad Instruments helped you discover the issue quickly!

üòÖ Duncan
üëç:skin_tone_3: Duncan
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:18:52

@Cristina asked > Hi! I hope this is the right room for this question. When releasing an app on the App Store, we can conveniently receive symbolicated crash reports via the App Store itself. Instead, when releasing apps by any other mean, like enterprise, I currently rely on Firebase Crashlytics, but it's not as convenient because since lately (a year or more) it's always missing dSYMs. Is there any official way that maybe I don't know to get crash reports from enterprise apps? Thank you!

Phillip A (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:19:39

*Thread Reply:* Hello. I'm glad to hear you're making use of the Xcode Organizer window!

Crash reporting in the Organizer can be used for TestFlight, App Store, and Custom App distributions. If it makes sense, I would consider using TestFlight or Custom App distribution where you may be using Enterprise or Ad Hoc distribution.

For distributions outside the App Store or TestFlight, you can collect Crash Logs from your users via the MetricKit framework within your code or ask the user to send you the log via the Settings menu. These latter options require keeping your dSYMs and performing local symbolication manually.

For more information on crash reporting in the Xcode Organizer window, dSYMs, and MetricKit, I recommend the following sessions:

https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2021/10203/ https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2021/10211/ https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2018/414/

These sessions include instructions on how to perform symbolication manually. If you can make use of the Organizer window symbolication is automatic.

Apple Developer
Triage TestFlight crashes in Xcode Organizer - WWDC21 - Videos - Apple Developer
Learn how Xcode Organizer makes it easier and faster to triage and fix crashes. We'll explore how you can get access to crash information...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2021/10203/
Apple Developer
Symbolication: Beyond the basics - WWDC21 - Videos - Apple Developer
Discover how you can achieve maximum performance and insightful debugging with your app. Symbolication is at the center of tools such as...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2021/10211/
Apple Developer
Understanding Crashes and Crash Logs - WWDC18 - Videos - Apple Developer
Sudden app crashes are a source of bad user experience and app review rejections. Learn how crash logs can be analyzed, what information...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2018/414/
:gratitude_thank_you: Cristina
Cristina
2022-06-09 21:29:36

*Thread Reply:* Thanks a lot! This is great! üëç:skintone2:

üëç Phillip A (Apple)
Cristina
2022-06-09 23:28:18

*Thread Reply:* Just to be sure, @Phillip A (Apple), are reports collected with MetricKit delivered to the organizer window as well? Is it because I‚Äôm signed into Xcode with an account belonging to the app‚Äôs signing team?

Phillip A (Apple)
2022-06-09 23:44:27

*Thread Reply:* MetricKit reports are delivered directly to your application via the framework. They're separate from the Organizer reports insofar that you'll need to upload and process them yourself. The reports you'll see in the Organizer window are coming from the same source as MetricKit (i.e., user devices,) but they are processed by Apple on your behalf and delivered to the Organizer if you are signed into Xcode with a developer account with access to the associated app.

Cristina
2022-06-09 23:45:45

*Thread Reply:* Ok, clear, so I can manually deliver them wherever I want, also on my server, am I right?

Phillip A (Apple)
2022-06-09 23:50:14

*Thread Reply:* Thats correct. MetricKit will provide you the logs themselves as objects defined in the API, and you can convert them to JSON objects for transport off device.

Cristina
2022-06-09 23:50:38

*Thread Reply:* Perfect, thank you very much!!

üíØ Phillip A (Apple)
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:34:03

@William asked > We release builds with a roughly 2-3 week cadence. App Store Connect opt-in metrics show many active devices + sessions each week. When I open the Xcode 13 organizer, I see crash reports but all the metrics views are marked "Insufficient Metrics Data." Is there a way to tell what the internal threshold is? Any tips on getting performance data from the wild? It seems like a very useful feature we've never been able to take advantage of

Phillip A (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:35:40

*Thread Reply:* Hi - thanks for the question! It would be great if we could have your apps bundleID to help investigate this. In the meantime, MetricKit is a good alternative to collect data from the wild on iOS and macOS. You'll be able to capture most of the same metrics/reports directly from the framework. For more information on MetricKit check out the documentation here: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/metrickit?language=objc

2022-06-09 21:39:35

William
2022-06-09 22:56:22

üëç Phillip A (Apple)
Enrico
2022-06-10 08:19:09

*Thread Reply:* And here‚Äôs mine: FB10148972

üëç Phillip A (Apple)
DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:39:55

@Ian asked > This is probably very basic, but I have an app that hangs after a few minutes of use and I‚Äôm having trouble tracking down the problem. It seems to have some kind of memory leak where some objects aren‚Äôt being deallocated as I would expect, but I‚Äôm not sure how to resolve that or even if that is the reason for the hang (the app isn‚Äôt crashing).

Joachim K (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:40:06

*Thread Reply:* Hi Ian, Memory leaks usually don't cause long hangs. A hang occurs when the main thread is not able to process incoming events. This is either because it is busy doing other things or because it is blocked waiting on something else to finish.

This year, we added Hang detection to Instruments. Just choose the "Time Profiler" template in Instruments and profile your app using it. If a hang occurs, it will show up in your process' track, right under the application lifecycle lane (the one showing whether your app is running in the foreground or in the background).

We also published a session today that goes into more detail about a bunch of tools for tracking down hangs this year. E.g. when you run your app from Xcode, Xcode will highlight common hang causes as runtime issues. Also, you can enable on-device hang detection in iOS to get notified of hangs while you are using the device and record them directly to export logs/traces and analyze them later. This way you don't need to have your device attached to Instruments all the time if it takes longer to reproduce.

Lastly, feel free to sign up for tomorrow's Performance, power, and stability lab and we are happy to take a look at this together with you. If you can reproduce the issue and share your screen during the Webex lab we can take a look together.

Apple Developer
Track down hangs with Xcode and on-device detection - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
Learn how you can increase responsiveness and eliminate hangs in your app and make even better experiences. Hang out with the Performance...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10082/
idmsa.apple.com
Sign In - Apple
Sign in with your Apple ID
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/labs-and-lounges/dashboard/TJ7F5J2CSP/dashboard
Duncan
2022-06-09 20:41:58

*Thread Reply:* This year, we added Hang detection to Instruments.

üÜí Sara, Ian
Duncan
2022-06-09 20:42:37

*Thread Reply:* Noice. üëè:skintone3:

üôå Tibet R (Apple), Joachim K (Apple), Ian
Ian
2022-06-09 22:35:18

*Thread Reply:* Excellent. Thanks. To get the new version of instruments do I need the new XCode beta?

Joachim K (Apple)
2022-06-10 02:47:08

*Thread Reply:* Yes, exactly, Instruments is bundled with Xcode. To get the Hang detection (both the one that shows up in Instruments as well as the on-device hang detection), you'll also need to run your app on the new operating systems (macOS Ventura, iOS 16, etc. depending on where your app lives), as only those have the corresponding instrumentation.

DevTools and Swift - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:41:41

@Iain asked > Hey all, I saw that Contents/SharedFrameworks/DVTFoundation.framework/Versions/A/Resources/symbolicatecrash is deprecated and I was wondering if there is a convenient alternative that can symbolicate a whole .crash file in a single command?

Anton V (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:42:19

*Thread Reply:* Hi. With new Xcode 14 Beta xcrun crashlog &lt;path/to/crash&gt; can be used to symbolicate crashes. To learn more take a look at help page xcrun crashlog --help.

ü§© Michal, Iain
Sara
2022-06-09 20:49:13

*Thread Reply:* I should use that instead of atos?

Harjas M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:59:58

*Thread Reply:* atos can be used for single address to symbol lookup. It is not meant to be used to symbolicate entire files by itself. xcrun crashlog is the appropriate tool to use to symbolicate an entire file.

Sara
2022-06-09 21:03:01

*Thread Reply:* Cool! Where's that documented? Last I could find in the Xcode 13.3 release notes was to use atos instead of symbolicatecrash

Harjas M (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:12:10

*Thread Reply:* You can find this in the Xcode 14 release notes: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/Xcode-Release-Notes/xcode-14-release-notes

Harjas M (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:12:17

*Thread Reply:* Hope that helps üòÑ

Sara
2022-06-09 21:13:24

*Thread Reply:* Great! Will https://developer.apple.com/documentation/Xcode/adding-identifiable-symbol-names-to-a-crash-report be updated as well? Not that it wasn't fun with atos in it but...(it wasn't üòÑ )

Joachim K (Apple)
2022-06-09 21:17:09

*Thread Reply:* That's a great point Sara, this documentation should definitely be updated. Could you please file a feedback? If you do, feel free to post the feedback ID here and we'll make sure it gets into the right hands.
